events.title: Silver's Calculated Lament and Shared Merriment with Jim
detailed_summary: Silver addresses Jim, lamenting the difficult situation Black Dog's escape has placed him in, particularly concerning Captain Trelawney's likely opinion.
He complains about the audacity of Black Dog sitting in his establishment, drinking his rum, and then managing to escape despite Jim plainly identifying him.
Silver pleads for Jim to represent him fairly to the captain, acknowledging Jim's youth but praising his astuteness.
He emphasizes his helplessness due to his wooden leg, claiming that in his prime as an able-bodied master mariner, he would have swiftly apprehended Black Dog.
Suddenly, Silver stops, his jaw dropping as if a crucial thought has just struck him.
He exclaims about Black Dog's unpaid bill for three measures of rum, feigning astonishment at having forgotten it.
He then collapses onto a bench, laughing until tears stream down his face. Jim cannot help but join in, and they laugh together boisterously until the tavern resounds.
Wiping his cheeks, Silver self-deprecatingly calls himself a 'precious old sea-calf' and suggests that he and Jim will get on well, humorously proposing he should be rated as a ship's boy.
He then abruptly shifts to a serious demeanor, stating that 'duty is duty' and they must go to Captain Trelawney to report the incident.

Silver acknowledges the seriousness of the matter and that neither of them has emerged from it with credit, then laughs heartily again about the unpaid score, compelling Jim to join in his mirth once more, despite not fully grasping the joke as Silver does.

events.text_segment:
“See here, now, Hawkins,” said he, “here’s a blessed hard thing on a man like me, now, ain’t it? There’s Cap’n Trelawney—what’s he to think? Here I have this confounded son of a Dutchman sitting in my own house drinking of my own rum! Here you comes and tells me of it plain; and here I let him give us all the slip before my blessed deadlights! Now, Hawkins, you do me justice with the cap’n. You’re a lad, you are, but you’re as smart as paint. I see that when you first come in. Now, here it is: What could I do, with this old timber I hobble on? When I was an A B master mariner I’d have come up alongside of him, hand over hand, and broached him to in a brace of old shakes, I would; but now—”
And then, all of a sudden, he stopped, and his jaw dropped as though he had remembered something.
“The score!” he burst out. “Three goes o’ rum! Why, shiver my timbers, if I hadn’t forgotten my score!”
And falling on a bench, he laughed until the tears ran down his cheeks. I could not help joining, and we laughed together, peal after peal, until the tavern rang again.
“Why, what a precious old sea-calf I am!” he said at last, wiping his cheeks. “You and me should get on well, Hawkins, for I’ll take my davy I should be rated ship’s boy. But come now, stand by to go about. This won’t do. Dooty is dooty, messmates. I’ll put on my old cockerel hat, and step along of you to Cap’n Trelawney, and report this here affair. For mind you, it’s serious, young Hawkins; and neither you nor me’s come out of it with what I should make so bold as to call credit. Nor you neither, says you; not smart—none of the pair of us smart. But dash my buttons! That was a good un about my score.”
And he began to laugh again, and that so heartily, that though I did not see the joke as he did, I was again obliged to join him in his mirth.

Here I have this irritating fellow sitting in my own home drinking my own liquor! You arrive and tell me about it plainly; and here I am letting him escape right in front of my eyes! Now, Hawkins, you must speak well of me to the captain. You are young, yes, but you’re incredibly sharp. I noticed that the moment you came in. So, listen: What could I possibly do with this bad leg I limp on? When I was a skilled master sailor, I would have quickly caught up to him, grabbed him fast, and overpowered him in no time at all; but now—” He then abruptly stopped, and his mouth fell open as if something had just occurred to him. “The bill!” he suddenly exclaimed. “Three servings of rum! Well, I’ll be amazed if I didn’t completely forget to collect my payment!” And collapsing onto a bench, he roared with laughter until tears streamed down his face. I couldn’t help but join in, and we laughed together, outburst after outburst, until the sound echoed through the tavern. “My word, what a foolish old sailor I am!” he said eventually, wiping his eyes. “You and I should get along well, Hawkins, because I swear I should be ranked as just a ship’s boy. But alright, let’s change tack. This won’t do. Duty is duty, comrades. I’ll put on my hat and accompany you to Captain Trelawney to report this whole incident. Because mark my words, it’s serious, young Hawkins; and neither you nor I have handled it in a way that I could confidently call commendable. Not you either, you might say; not quick-witted—neither of us was clever. But goodness me! Forgetting my bill was truly amusing.” And he started laughing again, and with such heartiness that, even though I didn't find the humour quite as profound as he did, I was compelled to join him in his merriment once more.

events.title: An Informative Stroll and Silver's Report to the Squire and Doctor
detailed_summary: During their walk along the quays to the inn, Long John Silver makes himself an exceptionally engaging companion for Jim.
He identifies the various ships they pass, explaining details about their rigging, tonnage, and country of origin.
Silver also clarifies the different types of work happening at the docks—one ship unloading cargo, another loading, a third preparing to set sail.
He frequently shares brief stories about ships or sailors, or repeats nautical terms until Jim has learned them thoroughly.
Through these interactions, Jim starts to view Silver as one of the best possible shipmates.
When they arrive at the inn, they find Squire Trelawney and Dr. Livesey finishing a quart of ale, containing a piece of toast, before their intended visit to inspect the schooner.

Long John recounts the story of Black Dog's appearance and escape from beginning to end, doing so with great animation and, in Jim's assessment, perfect truthfulness. He would occasionally turn to Jim for confirmation, saying something like, 'That was how it was, wasn't it, Hawkins?', and Jim was always able to fully support his account.

events.text_segment:
The Hispaniola lay some way out, and we went under the figureheads and round the sterns of many other ships, and their cables sometimes grated underneath our keel, and sometimes swung above us. At last, however, we got alongside, and were met and saluted as we stepped aboard by the mate, Mr. Arrow, a brown old sailor with earrings in his ears and a squint. He and the squire were very thick and friendly, but I soon observed that things were not the same between Mr. Trelawney and the captain.
This last was a sharp-looking man who seemed angry with everything on board and was soon to tell us why, for we had hardly got down into the cabin when a sailor followed us.
“Captain Smollett, sir, axing to speak with you,” said he.
“I am always at the captain’s orders. Show him in,” said the squire.
The captain, who was close behind his messenger, entered at once and shut the door behind him.

events.title: Captain Smollett's Unveiled Discontent
detailed_summary: Squire Trelawney initiates the conversation, asking Captain Smollett for his assessment of the ship and preparations.
Captain Smollett responds directly and bluntly, stating his dissatisfaction with the cruise, the crew, and his officer, Mr. Arrow.
Squire Trelawney, visibly angered, challenges Smollett, questioning if he also dislikes the ship and, implicitly, his employer.
Dr. Livesey calmly intervenes, advising against questions likely to cause ill feeling and insists that Smollett must elaborate on his stark pronouncements.
Smollett explains that he was hired under "sealed orders" but has discovered that every crew member below officer rank is better informed about the voyage's details than he is, which he deems unfair.
He reveals that he has learned from his own men that the voyage is a treasure hunt.

Smollett expresses his deep apprehension about treasure voyages in general, particularly those that are meant to be secret but have clearly been compromised, alluding to the widespread knowledge by suggesting the secret was "told to the parrot."
He concludes by stating his belief that neither Trelawney nor Livesey fully comprehend the severe risks involved, which he characterizes as a matter of life or death.

events.text_segment:
“Well, Captain Smollett, what have you to say? All well, I hope; all shipshape and seaworthy?”
“Well, sir,” said the captain, “better speak plain, I believe, even at the risk of offence. I don’t like this cruise; I don’t like the men; and I don’t like my officer. That’s short and sweet.”
“Perhaps, sir, you don’t like the ship?” inquired the squire, very angry, as I could see.
“I can’t speak as to that, sir, not having seen her tried,” said the captain. “She seems a clever craft; more I can’t say.”
“Possibly, sir, you may not like your employer, either?” says the squire.
But here Dr. Livesey cut in.
“Stay a bit,” said he, “stay a bit. No use of such questions as that but to produce ill feeling. The captain has said too much or he has said too little, and I’m bound to say that I require an explanation of his words. You don’t, you say, like this cruise. Now, why?”
“I was engaged, sir, on what we call sealed orders, to sail this ship for that gentleman where he should bid me,” said the captain. “So far so good. But now I find that every man before the mast knows more than I do. I don’t call that fair, now, do you?”
“No,” said Dr. Livesey, “I don’t.”
“Next,” said the captain, “I learn we are going after treasure—hear it from my own hands, mind you. Now, treasure is ticklish work; I don’t like treasure voyages on any account, and I don’t like them, above all, when they are secret and when (begging your pardon, Mr. Trelawney) the secret has been told to the parrot.”
“Silver’s parrot?” asked the squire.
“It’s a way of speaking,” said the captain. “Blabbed, I mean. It’s my belief neither of you gentlemen know what you are about, but I’ll tell you my way of it—life or death, and a close run.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
“So, Captain Smollett,” Squire Trelawney began, “how are things? I trust everything is in good order and the ship is ready and capable for sea?”

“Frankly, sir,” the captain replied, “I feel it’s best to be direct, even if it might cause offense. I do not care for this voyage; I am not pleased with the crew; and I disapprove of my first officer. That’s my concise opinion.”

“Perhaps, sir, you also have a problem with the vessel itself?” the squire asked, clearly irritated, as I could see.

“I cannot comment on the ship yet, sir, as she hasn’t been tested,” said the captain. “She appears to be a fine craft; that’s all I can say for now.”

“It’s possible, then, sir, that you might even dislike your employer?” the squire pressed.

However, Dr. Livesey interrupted at this point.

“Hold on,” he said, “just a moment. Such questions only serve to create animosity. The captain has either said too much or not enough, and I must insist he clarify his remarks. You claim you dislike this cruise. Could you explain why?”

“I was hired, sir, under what are known as sealed orders, to command this ship according to that gentleman’s directions,” the captain stated. “Initially, that was acceptable. But now I discover that every ordinary sailor knows more than I do. I don’t consider that fair, do you?”

“No,” Dr. Livesey agreed, “I do not.”

“Furthermore,” the captain continued, “I’ve learned we are pursuing treasure—and I heard this from the crew themselves, mind you. Now, treasure hunting is a risky business; I avoid treasure expeditions entirely, and most of all, I dislike them when they are supposed to be secret and when (with due respect, Mr. Trelawney) the secret has been carelessly revealed.”

“Do you mean Silver’s parrot?” inquired the squire.

“It’s a figure of speech,” the captain clarified. “I mean the secret has been spilled. It is my conviction that neither of you gentlemen truly grasp the seriousness of this undertaking, but I will tell you my assessment—it’s a matter of life and death, a very close call.”

“That is all clear, and, I dare say, true enough,” replied Dr. Livesey. “We take the risk, but we are not so ignorant as you believe us. Next, you say you don’t like the crew. Are they not good seamen?”
“I don’t like them, sir,” returned Captain Smollett. “And I think I should have had the choosing of my own hands, if you go to that.”
“Perhaps you should,” replied the doctor. “My friend should, perhaps, have taken you along with him; but the slight, if there be one, was unintentional. And you don’t like Mr. Arrow?”
“I don’t, sir. I believe he’s a good seaman, but he’s too free with the crew to be a good officer. A mate should keep himself to himself—shouldn’t drink with the men before the mast!”
“Do you mean he drinks?” cried the squire.
“No, sir,” replied the captain, “only that he’s too familiar.”
“Well, now, and the short and long of it, captain?” asked the doctor. “Tell us what you want.”
“Well, gentlemen, are you determined to go on this cruise?”
“Like iron,” answered the squire.
“Very good,” said the captain. “Then, as you’ve heard me very patiently, saying things that I could not prove, hear me a few words more. They are putting the powder and the arms in the fore hold. Now, you have a good place under the cabin; why not put them there?—first point. Then, you are bringing four of your own people with you, and they tell me some of them are to be berthed forward. Why not give them the berths here beside the cabin?—second point.”
“Any more?” asked Mr. Trelawney.
“One more,” said the captain. “There’s been too much blabbing already.”
“Far too much,” agreed the doctor.
“I’ll tell you what I’ve heard myself,” continued Captain Smollett: “that you have a map of an island, that there’s crosses on the map to show where treasure is, and that the island lies—” And then he named the latitude and longitude exactly.
“I never told that,” cried the squire, “to a soul!”
“The hands know it, sir,” returned the captain.
“Livesey, that must have been you or Hawkins,” cried the squire.
“It doesn’t much matter who it was,” replied the doctor. And I could see that neither he nor the captain paid much regard to Mr. Trelawney’s protestations. Neither did I, to be sure, he was so loose a talker; yet in this case I believe he was really right and that nobody had told the situation of the island.

detailed_summary: Captain Smollett continues, stating he doesn't know who possesses the map but insists it must be kept secret, even from himself and Mr. Arrow, or he will resign his command.
Dr. Livesey interprets Smollett's demands and concerns, suggesting the captain fears a mutiny.
Captain Smollett firmly objects to Livesey putting words in his mouth, asserting that no captain would set sail if he had definite grounds to state such a fear.

He clarifies that he believes Mr. Arrow is honest, and some of the men might be too, but as captain, he is responsible for the ship's safety and every life aboard; he perceives that things are not right and requests specific precautions or his resignation, stating that is all.

Dr. Livesey, with a slight smile, references the fable of the mountain and the mouse, implying that Smollett had initially intended a more dramatic outcome or had larger complaints when he first entered, suggesting he meant more than his stated requests.

Captain Smollett acknowledges Dr. Livesey's astuteness, admitting that his original intention upon entering the cabin was to be discharged from his position, as he hadn't expected Mr. Trelawney to entertain his concerns.

Captain Smollett stoically accepts Trelawney's sentiment, affirming that he will fulfill his duty regardless, and then departs.

events.text_segment:
“Well, gentlemen,” continued the captain, “I don’t know who has this map; but I make it a point, it shall be kept secret even from me and Mr. Arrow. Otherwise I would ask you to let me resign.”
“I see,” said the doctor. “You wish us to keep this matter dark and to make a garrison of the stern part of the ship, manned with my friend’s own people, and provided with all the arms and powder on board. In other words, you fear a mutiny.”
“Sir,” said Captain Smollett, “with no intention to take offence, I deny your right to put words into my mouth. No captain, sir, would be justified in going to sea at all if he had ground enough to say that. As for Mr. Arrow, I believe him thoroughly honest; some of the men are the same; all may be for what I know. But I am responsible for the ship’s safety and the life of every man Jack aboard of her. I see things going, as I think, not quite right. And I ask you to take certain precautions or let me resign my berth. And that’s all.”
“Captain Smollett,” began the doctor with a smile, “did ever you hear the fable of the mountain and the mouse? You’ll excuse me, I dare say, but you remind me of that fable. When you came in here, I’ll stake my wig, you meant more than this.”
“Doctor,” said the captain, “you are smart. When I came in here I meant to get discharged. I had no thought that Mr. Trelawney would hear a word.”
“No more I would,” cried the squire. “Had Livesey not been here I should have seen you to the deuce. As it is, I have heard you. I will do as you desire, but I think the worse of you.”
“That’s as you please, sir,” said the captain. “You’ll find I do my duty.”
And with that he took his leave.

events.title: Aftermath, Reflections, and Ship Reorganization
detailed_summary: Following Captain Smollett's departure, Dr. Livesey remarks to Squire Trelawney that, contrary to his expectations, Trelawney has managed to secure two honest individuals for the voyage: Captain Smollett and John Silver.

Squire Trelawney readily agrees regarding John Silver's honesty but expresses strong disdain for Captain Smollett, describing his conduct as unmanly, unsailorly, and un-English; Dr. Livesey cautiously responds, "Well, we shall see."

Upon returning to the deck, the narrator observes that the crew has already commenced the work of relocating the arms and powder, singing as they labor, while Captain Smollett and Mr. Arrow oversee the operations.

The narrator describes the newly implemented arrangements, which he personally finds agreeable; the schooner's layout has been significantly altered, with six berths created aft from part of the main hold.
These cabins are now connected to the galley and forecastle only by a narrow, sparred passage on the port side.

The original plan for these aft berths (intended for the captain, Mr. Arrow, Hunter, Joyce, the doctor, and the squire) is changed; Redruth and the narrator (Jim Hawkins) are now assigned two of these secure berths.

Consequently, Mr. Arrow and Captain Smollett are to sleep on deck in the companionway, which has been enlarged on each side to accommodate two hammocks, almost resembling a round-house, though still low.

The narrator notes that even Mr. Arrow seemed pleased with this new arrangement, speculating that perhaps Arrow also had reservations about the crew, though this is only a guess as Arrow's opinion would not be available for long.

This cluster of cabins was connected to the kitchen and the crew's living area in the bow (forecastle) only by a slatted walkway along the port (left) side. The initial plan was for the captain, Mr. Arrow, Hunter, Joyce, the doctor, and the squire to occupy these six berths. However, under the new plan, Redruth and the narrator were to take two of them, while Mr. Arrow and the captain were to sleep in the on-deck structure called the companionway. This area had been expanded outwards on both sides to the point where it could almost be called a small, low cabin or 'round-house'. Although still quite low, it was large enough to hang two hammocks, and even the mate, Mr. Arrow, seemed content with the setup. Perhaps even he had concerns about the crew, but that's just a guess, because, as you will learn, they didn't have the benefit of his opinion for much longer.

events.title: Long John Silver's Arrival and Captain Smollett's Stern Authority
detailed_summary: While everyone is engaged in relocating the powder and reconfiguring the berths, Long John Silver arrives with the last of the shore party.

Silver, agilely boarding the ship “like a monkey for cleverness,” immediately notices the ongoing work and inquires about it, expressing concern that the changes might cause them to miss the morning tide.
Captain Smollett briefly and authoritatively informs Silver that these are his orders and directs him to go below, as the crew will soon require supper.
Silver respectfully complies, touching his forelock before heading to his galley.
Dr. Livesey commends Silver to the captain, calling him a good man; Captain Smollett offers a noncommittal "Very likely, sir."
The captain continues to direct the men moving the powder, cautioning them to be careful.
Spotting the narrator, Jim Hawkins, examining the ship's swivel gun (a long brass nine-pounder), Captain Smollett sharply orders him away, telling him to find work with the cook.
As the narrator hurries off, he overhears Captain Smollett loudly declare to Dr. Livesey his intention to have no favorites on his ship.
The narrator concludes by stating that he fully shared Squire Trelawney's negative assessment of Captain Smollett at that moment, feeling a deep animosity towards him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We were all hard at work, changing the powder and the berths, when the last man or two, and Long John along with them, came off in a shore-boat.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I assure you I was quite of the squire’s way of thinking, and hated the captain deeply.

events.text_segment:
We were all hard at work, changing the powder and the berths, when the last man or two, and Long John along with them, came off in a shore-boat.
The cook came up the side like a monkey for cleverness, and as soon as he saw what was doing, “So ho, mates!” says he. “What’s this?”
“We’re a-changing of the powder, Jack,” answers one.
“Why, by the powers,” cried Long John, “if we do, we’ll miss the morning tide!”
“My orders!” said the captain shortly. “You may go below, my man. Hands will want supper.”
“Aye, aye, sir,” answered the cook, and touching his forelock, he disappeared at once in the direction of his galley.
“That’s a good man, captain,” said the doctor.
“Very likely, sir,” replied Captain Smollett. “Easy with that, men—easy,” he ran on, to the fellows who were shifting the powder; and then suddenly observing me examining the swivel we carried amidships, a long brass nine, “Here you, ship’s boy,” he cried, “out o’ that! Off with you to the cook and get some work.”
And then as I was hurrying off I heard him say, quite loudly, to the doctor, “I’ll have no favourites on my ship.”
I assure you I was quite of the squire’s way of thinking, and hated the captain deeply.

"We're swapping out the powder, Jack," someone responded.
"Good heavens," Long John exclaimed, "if we do that, we won't catch the morning tide!"
"Those are my orders!" the captain stated abruptly. "You can head below, my man. The crew will be expecting their evening meal."
"Understood, sir," the cook replied, and after touching his forehead respectfully, he vanished immediately in the direction of his kitchen area.
"He seems like a capable man, Captain," the doctor commented.
"Quite possibly, sir," Captain Smollett replied. "Careful there, lads—be gentle," he continued, addressing the sailors who were moving the powder barrels. Then, noticing me examining the large brass nine-pounder swivel gun mounted in the middle of the ship, he suddenly shouted, "You there, ship's helper! Get away from that! Go report to the cook and find something useful to do."
And as I hurried away, I distinctly heard him say to the doctor, quite loudly, "I will not tolerate favouritism among my crew."
Frankly, I completely agreed with the squire's view and harboured a deep dislike for the captain.

events.title: Departure Preparations and the Hispaniola Sets Sail with a Shanty
detailed_summary: The night before departure was chaotic with preparations and well-wishers visiting the squire.
Jim Hawkins found the work more strenuous than any night at the Admiral Benbow, leaving him extremely tired.
Despite his fatigue, Jim remained on deck, captivated by the novel sights and sounds of the ship preparing to sail before dawn.
He observed the quick commands, the boatswain's whistle, and the crew moving in the lamplight to man the capstan-bars.
A crew member requested Long John Silver, addressed as Barbecue, to sing a song.
Silver, using his crutch, readily agreed and began the familiar shanty, "Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest."
The entire crew joined in the chorus, "Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!", pushing the capstan bars with enthusiasm.
The song and the moment transported Jim back to the Admiral Benbow, imagining the old captain's voice in the singing.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: All that night we were in a great bustle getting things stowed in their place, and boatfuls of the squire’s friends, Mr. Blandly and the like, coming off to wish him a good voyage and a safe return.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Even at that exciting moment it carried me back to the old Admiral Benbow in a second, and I seemed to hear the voice of the captain piping in the chorus.

events.text_segment:
All that night we were in a great bustle getting things stowed in their place, and boatfuls of the squire’s friends, Mr. Blandly and the like, coming off to wish him a good voyage and a safe return. We never had a night at the Admiral Benbow when I had half the work; and I was dog-tired when, a little before dawn, the boatswain sounded his pipe and the crew began to man the capstan-bars. I might have been twice as weary, yet I would not have left the deck, all was so new and interesting to me—the brief commands, the shrill note of the whistle, the men bustling to their places in the glimmer of the ship’s lanterns.
“Now, Barbecue, tip us a stave,” cried one voice.
“The old one,” cried another.
“Aye, aye, mates,” said Long John, who was standing by, with his crutch under his arm, and at once broke out in the air and words I knew so well:
“Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—”
And then the whole crew bore chorus:—
“Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!”
And at the third “Ho!” drove the bars before them with a will.
Even at that exciting moment it carried me back to the old Admiral Benbow in a second, and I seemed to hear the voice of the captain piping in the chorus.

I had never been so busy during a night at the Admiral Benbow inn; I was utterly exhausted when, just before sunrise, the boatswain blew his whistle and the crew started working the capstan bars. I could have been twice as tired, yet I wouldn't have left the deck because everything was so new and fascinating to me—the sharp instructions, the high-pitched sound of the whistle, and the men rushing to their positions illuminated by the ship’s lanterns. One person shouted, “Come on, Barbecue, give us a tune!” Another called out, “Sing the usual one!” “Right you are, mates,” responded Long John, who was standing nearby with his crutch propped under his arm, and immediately began the melody and lyrics I recognized so well: “Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—” followed by the entire crew joining in the chorus: “Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!” With the third “Ho!”, they powerfully pushed the bars ahead of them. Even in that thrilling moment, it instantly brought me back to the old Admiral Benbow, and I seemed to hear the captain's voice joining the chorus.

Even in this thrilling moment, I was instantly reminded of the Admiral Benbow inn and imagined the captain’s voice joining in the song.

events.title: The Voyage to Treasure Island Begins with Ominous Foreshadowing
detailed_summary: The anchor was quickly raised, sails were set, and the Hispaniola started her journey, leaving the land behind.
Jim was unable to rest before the ship was fully underway towards Treasure Island.
The narrator, Jim, states he will not recount the entire voyage in detail, noting its general prosperity.
He affirms the Hispaniola was a good vessel, the crew skilled, and the captain competent.
However, Jim foreshadows that a few significant incidents occurred en route to Treasure Island which are important to relate.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But soon the anchor was short up; soon it was hanging dripping at the bows; soon the sails began to draw, and the land and shipping to flit by on either side; and before I could lie down to snatch an hour of slumber the Hispaniola had begun her voyage to the Isle of Treasure.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But before we came the length of Treasure Island, two or three things had happened which require to be known.

events.text_segment:
But soon the anchor was short up; soon it was hanging dripping at the bows; soon the sails began to draw, and the land and shipping to flit by on either side; and before I could lie down to snatch an hour of slumber the Hispaniola had begun her voyage to the Isle of Treasure.
I am not going to relate that voyage in detail. It was fairly prosperous. The ship proved to be a good ship, the crew were capable seamen, and the captain thoroughly understood his business. But before we came the length of Treasure Island, two or three things had happened which require to be known.

Before I could even lie down for a short rest, the Hispaniola had begun its voyage to Treasure Island. I will not describe that journey in full detail. It went quite well overall. The ship proved excellent, the crew were competent sailors, and the captain was very good at his job. However, before we reached Treasure Island, two or three incidents occurred that are important enough to mention.

The ship was sound, the sailors skilled, and the captain very competent. However, before we reached Treasure Island, a couple of noteworthy incidents took place that must be mentioned.

events.title: The Incompetence and Mysterious Demise of Mr. Arrow
detailed_summary: Mr. Arrow, the first mate, proved to be more problematic than Captain Smollett had anticipated.
He lacked control over the crew, who disregarded his authority.
More seriously, Arrow began showing signs of drunkenness at sea, including a hazy look, flushed face, and slurred speech.
He was frequently sent below deck in disgrace due to his condition.
His inebriation led to accidents, periods of incapacitation in his bunk, and occasional, brief returns to sobriety and duty.
The source of his alcohol remained a persistent mystery to everyone on board, despite their efforts to discover it.
When confronted, Arrow would either laugh (if drunk) or deny drinking anything but water (if sober).
His uselessness as an officer and negative influence, coupled with his self-destructive behavior, made his eventual disappearance one dark, rough night unsurprising and not particularly mourned.
Captain Smollett drily commented that Arrow going overboard saved them the effort of formally disciplining him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Arrow, first of all, turned out even worse than the captain had feared.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Overboard!” said the captain. “Well, gentlemen, that saves the trouble of putting him in irons.”

events.text_segment:
Mr. Arrow, first of all, turned out even worse than the captain had feared. He had no command among the men, and people did what they pleased with him. But that was by no means the worst of it, for after a day or two at sea he began to appear on deck with hazy eye, red cheeks, stuttering tongue, and other marks of drunkenness. Time after time he was ordered below in disgrace. Sometimes he fell and cut himself; sometimes he lay all day long in his little bunk at one side of the companion; sometimes for a day or two he would be almost sober and attend to his work at least passably.
In the meantime, we could never make out where he got the drink. That was the ship’s mystery. Watch him as we pleased, we could do nothing to solve it; and when we asked him to his face, he would only laugh if he were drunk, and if he were sober deny solemnly that he ever tasted anything but water.
He was not only useless as an officer and a bad influence amongst the men, but it was plain that at this rate he must soon kill himself outright, so nobody was much surprised, nor very sorry, when one dark night, with a head sea, he disappeared entirely and was seen no more.
“Overboard!” said the captain. “Well, gentlemen, that saves the trouble of putting him in irons.”

He was repeatedly ordered below deck in disgrace. His inebriation sometimes caused him to fall and hurt himself; on other occasions, he would stay in his small bed in his cabin for the entire day. There were times, though, when he would be nearly sober for a day or two and perform his duties at least tolerably well. All the while, we could never determine where he was getting the alcohol. That remained the great puzzle of the voyage. No matter how closely we watched him, we couldn't solve it; and when we confronted him directly, he would either laugh if he was drunk, or emphatically deny ever drinking anything but water if he was sober. Besides being ineffective as an officer and setting a poor example for the crew, it was obvious that his drinking would soon be fatal. Therefore, when he completely disappeared one dark night with a rough sea and was never seen again, few people were greatly surprised or particularly upset. "Overboard!" the captain declared. "Well, gentlemen, that prevents us from having to restrain him."

events.title: Crew Reorganization and Introduction to Israel Hands
detailed_summary: Following Mr. Arrow's disappearance, the ship lacked a mate, necessitating a promotion from the crew.
Job Anderson, the boatswain, was considered the most suitable candidate and effectively took on the mate's responsibilities while retaining his original title.
Mr. Trelawney's previous seafaring experience proved valuable, as he often took watch during calm weather.
Israel Hands, the coxswain, is introduced as a prudent, cunning, and seasoned sailor, deemed trustworthy in critical situations.
The narrator notes Hands' close association with Long John Silver, which serves as a transition to discussing the ship's cook.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But there we were, without a mate; and it was necessary, of course, to advance one of the men.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He was a great confidant of Long John Silver, and so the mention of his name leads me on to speak of our ship’s cook, Barbecue, as the men called him.

events.text_segment:
But there we were, without a mate; and it was necessary, of course, to advance one of the men. The boatswain, Job Anderson, was the likeliest man aboard, and though he kept his old title, he served in a way as mate. Mr. Trelawney had followed the sea, and his knowledge made him very useful, for he often took a watch himself in easy weather. And the coxswain, Israel Hands, was a careful, wily, old, experienced seaman who could be trusted at a pinch with almost anything.
He was a great confidant of Long John Silver, and so the mention of his name leads me on to speak of our ship’s cook, Barbecue, as the men called him.

events.title: Character Study: Long John Silver's Dexterity, Influence, and Deceptive Charm
detailed_summary: Long John Silver, the ship's cook nicknamed Barbecue, ingeniously managed his mobility with a crutch, often worn on a lanyard to free his hands.
He demonstrated impressive skill in navigating the ship and performing his duties, such as cooking, even in rough seas, by wedging his crutch for support.
He had rigged lines, humorously called "Long John’s earrings," to help him cross wider deck spaces with remarkable agility.
Some crewmen who knew him previously expressed sympathy for his current physical limitations.
The coxswain informed Jim that Silver was an educated man, capable of articulate speech, and exceptionally brave.
Silver commanded respect and obedience from the entire crew, partly due to his personable approach and willingness to help individuals.
He was consistently kind to Jim, welcoming him into his impeccably clean galley, where his parrot, Captain Flint, was caged.
Silver would engage Jim in conversation, introducing his parrot, named after the infamous buccaneer, which would screech "Pieces of eight!"
Silver claimed the parrot was ancient, had witnessed immense wickedness, and sailed with notable pirates like Captain England, learning its phrases from plundered treasure ships.
The parrot also mimicked nautical commands like "Stand by to go about."

Silver would muse on the parrot's profanity, suggesting that exposure to wickedness corrupts even an innocent creature, yet his solemn demeanor in these moments convinced Jim of his inherent goodness.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Aboard ship he carried his crutch by a lanyard round his neck, to have both hands as free as possible.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And John would touch his forelock with a solemn way he had that made me think he was the best of men.

events.text_segment:
Aboard ship he carried his crutch by a lanyard round his neck, to have both hands as free as possible. It was something to see him wedge the foot of the crutch against a bulkhead, and propped against it, yielding to every movement of the ship, get on with his cooking like someone safe ashore. Still more strange was it to see him in the heaviest of weather cross the deck. He had a line or two rigged up to help him across the widest spaces—Long John’s earrings, they were called; and he would hand himself from one place to another, now using the crutch, now trailing it alongside by the lanyard, as quickly as another man could walk. Yet some of the men who had sailed with him before expressed their pity to see him so reduced.
“He’s no common man, Barbecue,” said the coxswain to me. “He had good schooling in his young days and can speak like a book when so minded; and brave—a lion’s nothing alongside of Long John! I seen him grapple four and knock their heads together—him unarmed.”
All the crew respected and even obeyed him. He had a way of talking to each and doing everybody some particular service. To me he was unweariedly kind, and always glad to see me in the galley, which he kept as clean as a new pin, the dishes hanging up burnished and his parrot in a cage in one corner.
“Come away, Hawkins,” he would say; “come and have a yarn with John. Nobody more welcome than yourself, my son. Sit you down and hear the news. Here’s Cap’n Flint—I calls my parrot Cap’n Flint, after the famous buccaneer—here’s Cap’n Flint predicting success to our v’yage. Wasn’t you, Cap’n?”
And the parrot would say, with great rapidity, “Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight!” till you wondered that it was not out of breath, or till John threw his handkerchief over the cage.
“Now, that bird,” he would say, “is, maybe, two hundred years old, Hawkins—they live forever mostly; and if anybody’s seen more wickedness, it must be the devil himself. She’s sailed with England, the great Cap’n England, the pirate. She’s been at Madagascar, and at Malabar, and Surinam, and Providence, and Portobello. She was at the fishing up of the wrecked plate ships. It’s there she learned ‘Pieces of eight,’ and little wonder; three hundred and fifty thousand of ’em, Hawkins! She was at the boarding of the Viceroy of the Indies out of Goa, she was; and to look at her you would think she was a babby. But you smelt powder—didn’t you, Cap’n?”
“Stand by to go about,” the parrot would scream.
“Ah, she’s a handsome craft, she is,” the cook would say, and give her sugar from his pocket, and then the bird would peck at the bars and swear straight on, passing belief for wickedness. “There,” John would add, “you can’t touch pitch and not be mucked, lad. Here’s this poor old innocent bird o’ mine swearing blue fire, and none the wiser, you may lay to that. She would swear the same, in a manner of speaking, before chaplain.” And John would touch his forelock with a solemn way he had that made me think he was the best of men.

On the ship, he wore his crutch on a cord around his neck, keeping his hands as free as possible. It was a striking sight to watch him brace the crutch against a wall and, balanced there, move with the ship as he cooked, just as if he were safely on land. Even more remarkable was seeing him make his way across the deck during rough weather. He had set up a few ropes, called Long John’s earrings, to help him traverse the widest sections; he would swing himself along, sometimes using the crutch and other times letting it hang by the cord, moving as quickly as any able-bodied man. Yet, some crew members who had sailed with him before felt sorry to see him in such a state. 

“He’s no ordinary man, Barbecue,” the coxswain told me. “He had a good education when he was young and can speak eloquently if he chooses; and brave—a lion has nothing on Long John! I’ve seen him take on four men at once and knock their heads together, even without a weapon.”

All the sailors respected and often obeyed him. He had a unique way of speaking to each person and doing everyone a personal favor. He was always incredibly kind to me, happy to welcome me to the galley, which he kept spotless, with shiny dishes hanging up and his parrot in a cage off to one side.

“Come in, Hawkins,” he’d say. “Come have a chat with John. No one is more welcome than you, my boy. Sit down and hear the latest. Here’s Cap’n Flint—I named my parrot after the famous pirate—predicting good fortune for our voyage. Aren’t you, Cap’n?”

And the parrot would rapidly squawk, “Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight!” until you wondered how it didn’t tire out, or until John covered the cage with a cloth.

"Now, that bird," he’d continue, "must be about two hundred years old, Hawkins—they live forever, pretty much; and if anyone has seen more wickedness, it must be the devil himself. She’s sailed with Captain England, the pirate. She’s been to Madagascar, Malabar, Surinam, Providence, and Portobello. She was there when they recovered treasure from sunken ships. That’s where she learned the phrase ‘Pieces of eight,’ which makes sense—there were three hundred and fifty thousand of them, Hawkins! She was also there for the attack on the Viceroy of the Indies from Goa. And look at her—you’d think she was an innocent baby. But she’s been around gunpowder—right, Cap’n?”

“Stand by to go about,” the parrot would screech.

“She’s a beauty, she is,” John would say, giving her sugar from his pocket, and the parrot would peck at the bars and start cursing with astonishing foulness. “See, you can’t touch pitch and not get dirty, lad. Here’s my poor old innocent bird cursing up a storm without even understanding it. She’d curse just the same, even in front of a chaplain.” And John would gesture respectfully in a way that made me think he was truly a good man.

events.text_segment:
In the meantime, the squire and Captain Smollett were still on pretty distant terms with one another. The squire made no bones about the matter; he despised the captain. The captain, on his part, never spoke but when he was spoken to, and then sharp and short and dry, and not a word wasted. He owned, when driven into a corner, that he seemed to have been wrong about the crew, that some of them were as brisk as he wanted to see and all had behaved fairly well. As for the ship, he had taken a downright fancy to her. “She’ll lie a point nearer the wind than a man has a right to expect of his own married wife, sir. But,” he would add, “all I say is, we’re not home again, and I don’t like the cruise.”
The squire, at this, would turn away and march up and down the deck, chin in air.
“A trifle more of that man,” he would say, “and I shall explode.”
We had some heavy weather, which only proved the qualities of the Hispaniola. Every man on board seemed well content, and they must have been hard to please if they had been otherwise, for it is my belief there was never a ship’s company so spoiled since Noah put to sea. Double grog was going on the least excuse; there was duff on odd days, as, for instance, if the squire heard it was any man’s birthday, and always a barrel of apples standing broached in the waist for anyone to help himself that had a fancy.
“Never knew good come of it yet,” the captain said to Dr. Livesey. “Spoil forecastle hands, make devils. That’s my belief.”

events.title: The Apple Barrel's Foreshadowed Importance as Treasure Island Nears

They were now sailing directly for the island, maintaining a vigilant lookout.
It was believed to be the final day of their outward journey, with Treasure Island expected to be sighted that night or by the next morning at the latest.
The ship sailed smoothly with a steady breeze and calm seas.
The crew was in high spirits, anticipating the imminent conclusion of the first leg of their adventure.

But good did come of the apple barrel, as you shall hear, for if it had not been for that, we should have had no note of warning and might all have perished by the hand of treachery.
This was how it came about.
We had run up the trades to get the wind of the island we were after—I am not allowed to be more plain—and now we were running down for it with a bright lookout day and night. It was about the last day of our outward voyage by the largest computation; some time that night, or at latest before noon of the morrow, we should sight the Treasure Island. We were heading S.S.W. and had a steady breeze abeam and a quiet sea. The Hispaniola rolled steadily, dipping her bowsprit now and then with a whiff of spray. All was drawing alow and aloft; everyone was in the bravest spirits because we were now so near an end of the first part of our adventure.

events.title: Jim's Accidental Overhearing of Silver's Treacherous Plot in the Apple Barrel
detailed_summary: After sunset, with his duties completed, Jim decided he wanted an apple.
He went on deck, noting the watch was positioned forward, looking for the island, and the helmsman was quietly whistling.
Jim climbed completely inside the nearly empty apple barrel.
Lulled by the ship's motion and the sound of the water, he either fell asleep or was close to it.
He was abruptly jolted when a heavy man sat down near the barrel, causing it to shake as he leaned against it.
As Jim was about to reveal himself, the man began to speak.
Recognizing the voice as Long John Silver's, Jim was instantly petrified by the first few words he heard.
Overcome by extreme fear and curiosity, he remained hidden, realizing from Silver's initial remarks that he had stumbled upon a secret that placed the lives of all loyal crew members in his hands.

events.text_segment:
Now, just after sundown, when all my work was over and I was on my way to my berth, it occurred to me that I should like an apple. I ran on deck. The watch was all forward looking out for the island. The man at the helm was watching the luff of the sail and whistling away gently to himself, and that was the only sound excepting the swish of the sea against the bows and around the sides of the ship.
In I got bodily into the apple barrel, and found there was scarce an apple left; but sitting down there in the dark, what with the sound of the waters and the rocking movement of the ship, I had either fallen asleep or was on the point of doing so when a heavy man sat down with rather a clash close by. The barrel shook as he leaned his shoulders against it, and I was just about to jump up when the man began to speak. It was Silver’s voice, and before I had heard a dozen words, I would not have shown myself for all the world, but lay there, trembling and listening, in the extreme of fear and curiosity, for from these dozen words I understood that the lives of all the honest men aboard depended upon me alone.

I quickly went up onto the deck. The ship's watch was all positioned near the bow, looking out for the island. The sailor steering the ship was keeping an eye on the sail's edge and quietly humming to himself. These were the only sounds, apart from the waves splashing against the front and sides of the vessel. I climbed completely into the apple barrel, only to find that there were very few apples left. Sitting there in the darkness, between the sounds of the water and the ship's gentle rocking, I was either asleep or on the verge of falling asleep when a heavy person sat down nearby with a distinct thud. The barrel shook as he leaned against it, and I was just about to get up when the person began speaking. It was Silver's voice, and after hearing only a few sentences, I decided I would not have revealed myself for any price, instead lying there, shaking and listening, overwhelmed by both fear and curiosity. This was because, based on those initial words, I understood that the survival of all the loyal crew members on board relied entirely on me.

I climbed right into the apple barrel, but there were hardly any apples left. Sitting in the darkness, lulled by the movements of the ship and the sound of the water, I must have either fallen asleep or was very close to it. Suddenly, a heavy man sat down noisily nearby, making the barrel tremble as he leaned against it. Just as I was about to get up, he started speaking—it was Silver. I lay there, shaking with fear and curiosity, because I could tell from what he was saying that the fate of all the good men on the ship rested entirely on me.

events.title: Silver Recounts Pirate History and His Financial Strategy
detailed_summary: Silver clarifies his role under Captain Flint was quartermaster, not captain, and mentions losing his leg in the same naval action where old Pew lost his eyesight.

He laments the fate of the skilled surgeon who amputated his leg, hanged at Corso Castle, and expresses his belief that ships should retain their original names, citing the Cassandra and Flint's old ship, the Walrus, which he recalls being stained with blood and heavy with gold.
The youngest sailor present voices admiration for Flint, calling him the 'flower of the flock'.
Silver acknowledges Davis as a capable pirate but states his own service was first with England, then with Flint, and now he operates independently.
He reveals his financial prudence, having saved nine hundred pounds from his time with England and two thousand after Flint, emphasizing that saving, not merely earning, is crucial.

He contrasts his own financial security with the current state of England's and Flint's former crewmen, many of whom are now impoverished and serving on their current ship, having previously been reduced to begging.
Silver uses Old Pew as an example of profligacy, describing how Pew squandered twelve hundred pounds annually before ending up starving, begging, stealing, and murdering, ultimately dying destitute.
The young seaman remarks that such a life seems ultimately futile.
Silver counters that it's only futile for fools and then begins to flatter the young seaman, calling him intelligent, using the exact same compliments he had previously used on Jim Hawkins.
Jim, concealed in the apple barrel, is filled with rage upon hearing Silver's manipulative flattery directed at another, wishing he could kill him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: No, not I,” said Silver.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: You may imagine how I felt when I heard this abominable old rogue addressing another in the very same words of flattery as he had used to myself. I think, if I had been able, that I would have killed him through the barrel. Meantime, he ran on, little supposing he was overheard.

events.text_segment:
No, not I,” said Silver. “Flint was cap’n; I was quartermaster, along of my timber leg. The same broadside I lost my leg, old Pew lost his deadlights. It was a master surgeon, him that ampytated me—out of college and all—Latin by the bucket, and what not; but he was hanged like a dog, and sun-dried like the rest, at Corso Castle. That was Roberts’ men, that was, and comed of changing names to their ships—Royal Fortune and so on. Now, what a ship was christened, so let her stay, I says. So it was with the Cassandra, as brought us all safe home from Malabar, after England took the Viceroy of the Indies; so it was with the old Walrus, Flint’s old ship, as I’ve seen amuck with the red blood and fit to sink with gold.”
“Ah!” cried another voice, that of the youngest hand on board, and evidently full of admiration. “He was the flower of the flock, was Flint!”
“Davis was a man too, by all accounts,” said Silver. “I never sailed along of him; first with England, then with Flint, that’s my story; and now here on my own account, in a manner of speaking. I laid by nine hundred safe, from England, and two thousand after Flint. That ain’t bad for a man before the mast—all safe in bank. ’Tain’t earning now, it’s saving does it, you may lay to that. Where’s all England’s men now? I dunno. Where’s Flint’s? Why, most on ’em aboard here, and glad to get the duff—been begging before that, some on ’em. Old Pew, as had lost his sight, and might have thought shame, spends twelve hundred pound in a year, like a lord in Parliament. Where is he now? Well, he’s dead now and under hatches; but for two year before that, shiver my timbers, the man was starving! He begged, and he stole, and he cut throats, and starved at that, by the powers!”
“Well, it ain’t much use, after all,” said the young seaman.
“’Tain’t much use for fools, you may lay to it—that, nor nothing,” cried Silver. “But now, you look here: you’re young, you are, but you’re as smart as paint. I see that when I set my eyes on you, and I’ll talk to you like a man.”
You may imagine how I felt when I heard this abominable old rogue addressing another in the very same words of flattery as he had used to myself. I think, if I had been able, that I would have killed him through the barrel. Meantime, he ran on, little supposing he was overheard.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Silver clarified, saying, "Certainly not me. Flint was the captain; I served as quartermaster because of my wooden leg. I lost my leg during the same naval engagement where old Pew lost his eyesight. My leg was amputated by a highly skilled surgeon, a university graduate knowledgeable in many things, including fluent Latin. However, he was later executed and left to hang and dry in the sun like the others at Corso Castle by Roberts’ men, who were known for constantly renaming their ships, like the Royal Fortune, which I think is a bad practice." Silver added his belief that a ship should keep the name it was originally given. He cited the *Cassandra*, which brought them safely back from Malabar after England captured the *Viceroy of the Indies*, and the infamous old *Walrus*, Flint's vessel, which he had witnessed covered in blood and so laden with gold it seemed on the verge of sinking.

“No, not me,” said Silver. “Flint was the captain, while I served as quartermaster, thanks to my wooden leg. The very attack that cost me my leg also blinded old Pew. A top-notch surgeon, fresh out of university and full of Latin phrases, amputated my leg—yet he wound up hanged and left to dry in the sun at Corso Castle. That was the work of Roberts’ men, who got in trouble for renaming their ships—Royal Fortune and such. My view is: when a ship’s named, she should keep her name. Take the Cassandra, which safely brought us back from Malabar after England captured the Viceroy of the Indies, or Flint’s old ship, the Walrus—I’ve seen her awash in blood and weighed down with treasure.”

“Ah!” said the youngest crewmate, clearly impressed. “Flint was the best of them all!”

“Davis was a fine man too, or so I’ve heard,” Silver replied. “I never sailed with him myself—first I sailed with England, then with Flint. That’s my story. Now I’m acting on my own. I set aside nine hundred from my days with England, and two thousand after Flint. Not bad for someone before the mast, all secure in the bank. These days it’s about saving, not earning, you can believe that. Where are England’s men now? I don’t know. Where are Flint’s? Most of them are here, happy for even simple food—some used to beg. Old Pew, who was blind and should’ve felt shame, spent twelve hundred pounds in a year, like a lord. Where is he now? Dead and buried. But for two years before that, curse me, he was starving! He begged, stole, murdered, and still starved.”

“Well, it doesn’t seem worth it,” said the young sailor.

“It’s worthless for fools, I tell you—and that goes for anything,” Silver replied. “But listen here: you’re young, but you’re sharp. I saw that right away, and I’ll speak to you like a man.”

You can imagine my feelings when I heard this despicable old scoundrel using the same words of praise on someone else that he’d said to me. If I’d have had the chance, I’d have shot him then and there. Meanwhile, he kept talking, not realizing he was being overheard.

events.title: Silver Manipulates Dick and Reveals His Secured Fortune
detailed_summary: Silver elaborates on the life of 'gentlemen of fortune' (pirates), describing it as arduous and perilous but offering substantial financial rewards compared to the meager wages of ordinary sailors.

He highlights his own methodical approach to saving, distributing his wealth in various locations to avoid suspicion, unlike most pirates who quickly dissipate their earnings on alcohol and leisure before returning to sea impoverished.

Silver declares his age as fifty and his plan to retire as a true gentleman after the current voyage, asserting that he has maintained a comfortable lifestyle, indulging his desires except when at sea.
He emphasizes to Dick that his own career began humbly, as a common sailor, just like Dick's.
Dick questions Silver about the security of his accumulated wealth, suggesting it would be inaccessible if Silver cannot return to Bristol.
Silver mockingly inquires where Dick presumed his money was kept.
Dick supposes it is in banks or other establishments in Bristol.
Silver confirms it was in Bristol when they embarked, but reveals that his wife ('old missis') now possesses all of it, and that his inn, the Spy-glass, has been sold completely.
He mentions his wife is en route to meet him at an undisclosed location, which he keeps secret to prevent jealousy among the crew.
When Dick asks if Silver can trust his wife, Silver remarks that trust is a rare commodity among pirates.

Silver then boasts of his intimidating reputation, claiming that even the formidable Captain Flint was afraid of him, despite leading the most ruthless crew afloat, and assures Dick of his safety under his command.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Here it is about gentlemen of fortune.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Ah, you may be sure of yourself in old John’s ship.”

events.text_segment:
“Here it is about gentlemen of fortune. They lives rough, and they risk swinging, but they eat and drink like fighting-cocks, and when a cruise is done, why, it’s hundreds of pounds instead of hundreds of farthings in their pockets. Now, the most goes for rum and a good fling, and to sea again in their shirts. But that’s not the course I lay. I puts it all away, some here, some there, and none too much anywheres, by reason of suspicion. I’m fifty, mark you; once back from this cruise, I set up gentleman in earnest. Time enough too, says you. Ah, but I’ve lived easy in the meantime, never denied myself o’ nothing heart desires, and slep’ soft and ate dainty all my days but when at sea. And how did I begin? Before the mast, like you!”
“Well,” said the other, “but all the other money’s gone now, ain’t it? You daren’t show face in Bristol after this.”
“Why, where might you suppose it was?” asked Silver derisively.
“At Bristol, in banks and places,” answered his companion.
“It were,” said the cook; “it were when we weighed anchor. But my old missis has it all by now. And the Spy-glass is sold, lease and goodwill and rigging; and the old girl’s off to meet me. I would tell you where, for I trust you, but it’d make jealousy among the mates.”
“And can you trust your missis?” asked the other.
“Gentlemen of fortune,” returned the cook, “usually trusts little among themselves, and right they are, you may lay to it. But I have a way with me, I have. When a mate brings a slip on his cable—one as knows me, I mean—it won’t be in the same world with old John. There was some that was feared of Pew, and some that was feared of Flint; but Flint his own self was feared of me. Feared he was, and proud. They was the roughest crew afloat, was Flint’s; the devil himself would have been feared to go to sea with them. Well now, I tell you, I’m not a boasting man, and you seen yourself how easy I keep company, but when I was quartermaster, lambs wasn’t the word for Flint’s old buccaneers. Ah, you may be sure of yourself in old John’s ship.”

events.title: Dick Commits to Mutiny; Israel Hands Expresses Impatience
detailed_summary: Dick confesses to Silver that he was initially apprehensive about their mutinous undertaking but, after their conversation, is now fully committed, sealing his pledge with a handshake.
Silver commends Dick for his bravery and intelligence, shaking his hand so vigorously that the apple barrel where Jim is hiding trembles.
Jim, overhearing this exchange, fully grasps that 'gentleman of fortune' is a euphemism for pirate and realizes he has witnessed the final stage of an honest sailor's corruption.
Silver then whistles, summoning a third man, who is revealed to be Israel Hands, the ship's coxswain.
Silver informs Hands that Dick has joined their conspiracy ('Dick's square').
Hands acknowledges Dick's allegiance, remarking that Dick is not a fool.

Hands then voices his impatience, complaining about Captain Smollett's command and questioning how long they must wait before seizing control of the ship and its desirable stores, such as pickles and wine.
Silver admonishes Israel for his poor judgment, instructing him to remain in his designated area, maintain a low profile, and stay sober until he gives the order to act.
Israel grumbles in reluctant agreement but persists in asking when they will proceed with their plan.

“Well, I tell you now,” replied the lad, “I didn’t half a quarter like the job till I had this talk with you, John; but there’s my hand on it now.”
“And a brave lad you were, and smart too,” answered Silver, shaking hands so heartily that all the barrel shook, “and a finer figurehead for a gentleman of fortune I never clapped my eyes on.”
By this time I had begun to understand the meaning of their terms. By a “gentleman of fortune” they plainly meant neither more nor less than a common pirate, and the little scene that I had overheard was the last act in the corruption of one of the honest hands—perhaps of the last one left aboard. But on this point I was soon to be relieved, for Silver giving a little whistle, a third man strolled up and sat down by the party.
“Dick’s square,” said Silver.
“Oh, I know’d Dick was square,” returned the voice of the coxswain, Israel Hands. “He’s no fool, is Dick.” And he turned his quid and spat. “But look here,” he went on, “here’s what I want to know, Barbecue: how long are we a-going to stand off and on like a blessed bumboat? I’ve had a’most enough o’ Cap’n Smollett; he’s hazed me long enough, by thunder! I want to go into that cabin, I do. I want their pickles and wines, and that.”
“Israel,” said Silver, “your head ain’t much account, nor ever was. But you’re able to hear, I reckon; leastways, your ears is big enough. Now, here’s what I say: you’ll berth forward, and you’ll live hard, and you’ll speak soft, and you’ll keep sober till I give the word; and you may lay to that, my son.”
“Well, I don’t say no, do I?” growled the coxswain. “What I say is, when? That’s what I say.”

events.title: Silver Details His Mutiny Strategy and Criticizes Crew's Recklessness
detailed_summary: Silver emphatically states his intention to delay the mutiny until the very last feasible moment.
He outlines his strategy: to allow Captain Smollett to navigate the ship, and for the squire and doctor to locate the treasure and assist in loading it aboard before the mutineers make their move.
He expresses a desire, were his crew more trustworthy, to have Smollett sail them halfway back to their destination before seizing control.
Dick interjects, suggesting that all of them aboard are capable seamen.
Silver dismisses this, clarifying that they are merely 'forecastle hands' skilled at steering but lacking the expertise to set a course, a common failing he attributes to pirates generally.

He reveals his preference to have Captain Smollett navigate them back into the trade winds to ensure a safe voyage and adequate provisions, but concedes he will likely have to deal with the officers at the island once the treasure is secured, expressing frustration with his crew's fixation on immediate drunkenness.
Israel Hands advises Silver to remain calm and asks who is opposing his plans.
Silver retorts by recounting his extensive maritime experience, having witnessed numerous ships captured and many young sailors executed due to their haste and impatience.
He argues that with discipline and careful planning, they could achieve great wealth, but their impulsiveness and craving for immediate gratification, particularly rum, will be their undoing.
Israel counters, likening Silver to a moralizing chaplain and suggesting that other pirates who enjoyed life's pleasures were also competent, not as austere as Silver.
Silver dismissively cites the fates of Pew, who died a beggar, and Flint, who died from alcoholism in Savannah, as examples of such pleasure-seeking pirates, questioning their ultimate success.

events.text_segment:
“When! By the powers!” cried Silver. “Well now, if you want to know, I’ll tell you when. The last moment I can manage, and that’s when. Here’s a first-rate seaman, Cap’n Smollett, sails the blessed ship for us. Here’s this squire and doctor with a map and such—I don’t know where it is, do I? No more do you, says you. Well then, I mean this squire and doctor shall find the stuff, and help us to get it aboard, by the powers. Then we’ll see. If I was sure of you all, sons of double Dutchmen, I’d have Cap’n Smollett navigate us half-way back again before I struck.”
“Why, we’re all seamen aboard here, I should think,” said the lad Dick.
“We’re all forecastle hands, you mean,” snapped Silver. “We can steer a course, but who’s to set one? That’s what all you gentlemen split on, first and last. If I had my way, I’d have Cap’n Smollett work us back into the trades at least; then we’d have no blessed miscalculations and a spoonful of water a day. But I know the sort you are. I’ll finish with ’em at the island, as soon’s the blunt’s on board, and a pity it is. But you’re never happy till you’re drunk. Split my sides, I’ve a sick heart to sail with the likes of you!”
“Easy all, Long John,” cried Israel. “Who’s a-crossin’ of you?”
“Why, how many tall ships, think ye, now, have I seen laid aboard? And how many brisk lads drying in the sun at Execution Dock?” cried Silver. “And all for this same hurry and hurry and hurry. You hear me? I seen a thing or two at sea, I have. If you would on’y lay your course, and a p’int to windward, you would ride in carriages, you would. But not you! I know you. You’ll have your mouthful of rum tomorrow, and go hang.”
“Everybody knowed you was a kind of a chapling, John; but there’s others as could hand and steer as well as you,” said Israel. “They liked a bit o’ fun, they did. They wasn’t so high and dry, nohow, but took their fling, like jolly companions every one.”
“So?” says Silver. “Well, and where are they now? Pew was that sort, and he died a beggar-man. Flint was, and he died of rum at Savannah. Ah, they was a sweet crew, they was! On’y, where are they?”

events.title: Mutineers Plan Murder; Jim Overhears Crucial News and Land is Sighted
detailed_summary: Dick inquires about the intended fate of the loyal crew members after the mutineers seize control.

Silver commends Dick for his pragmatic question and contrasts two historical approaches: Captain England's method of marooning captives, versus the more brutal tactic of outright slaughter favored by Captain Flint or Billy Bones.
Israel Hands affirms Billy Bones's ruthlessness, recalling his maxim that 'dead men don't bite,' and noting that Bones himself is now deceased.

Silver acknowledges Billy's 'rough and ready' nature but asserts that despite his own generally amiable disposition, the current situation demands severity; he casts his vote for killing all loyalists.

He explains his reasoning: he wants no survivors ('sea-lawyers') to potentially reappear and threaten his comfortable retirement. He advocates patience until the opportune moment, then decisive, lethal action.
Israel Hands expresses admiration for Silver's resolute stance.
Silver then declares his personal intention to kill Trelawney, graphically vowing to wring his neck. He then abruptly asks Dick to fetch him an apple to 'wet his pipe'.
Jim, still hidden in the apple barrel, is overcome with terror at Silver's request, feeling too paralyzed to escape.
As Dick begins to rise, Israel Hands intervenes, suggesting they have rum instead, disparaging the apples as 'bilge'.
Silver agrees, providing Dick with the key to the rum keg but cautioning him about the gauge, implying a need for rationing.
Jim reflects that this secretive provision of alcohol must have been how Mr. Arrow, a former officer, was supplied with the spirits that led to his downfall.

While Dick is briefly absent fetching the rum, Jim overhears a crucial snippet of conversation between Israel and Silver: 'Not another man of them'll jine.' This reveals to Jim that there are still crew members loyal to the captain.

Upon Dick's return, the three mutineers take turns drinking from the pannikin, offering toasts to 'luck,' 'old Flint,' and Silver leading a chant-like toast to themselves, future prizes, and plentiful food.
At that moment, moonlight illuminates Jim's hiding place in the barrel. Simultaneously, the lookout's cry of 'Land ho!' pierces the night.

events.text_segment:
“But,” asked Dick, “when we do lay ’em athwart, what are we to do with ’em, anyhow?”
“There’s the man for me!” cried the cook admiringly. “That’s what I call business. Well, what would you think? Put ’em ashore like maroons? That would have been England’s way. Or cut ’em down like that much pork? That would have been Flint’s, or Billy Bones’s.”
“Billy was the man for that,” said Israel. “‘Dead men don’t bite,’ says he. Well, he’s dead now hisself; he knows the long and short on it now; and if ever a rough hand come to port, it was Billy.”
“Right you are,” said Silver; “rough and ready. But mark you here, I’m an easy man—I’m quite the gentleman, says you; but this time it’s serious. Dooty is dooty, mates. I give my vote—death. When I’m in Parlyment and riding in my coach, I don’t want none of these sea-lawyers in the cabin a-coming home, unlooked for, like the devil at prayers. Wait is what I say; but when the time comes, why, let her rip!”
“John,” cries the coxswain, “you’re a man!”
“You’ll say so, Israel when you see,” said Silver. “Only one thing I claim—I claim Trelawney. I’ll wring his calf’s head off his body with these hands, Dick!” he added, breaking off. “You just jump up, like a sweet lad, and get me an apple, to wet my pipe like.”
You may fancy the terror I was in! I should have leaped out and run for it if I had found the strength, but my limbs and heart alike misgave me. I heard Dick begin to rise, and then someone seemingly stopped him, and the voice of Hands exclaimed, “Oh, stow that! Don’t you get sucking of that bilge, John. Let’s have a go of the rum.”
“Dick,” said Silver, “I trust you. I’ve a gauge on the keg, mind. There’s the key; you fill a pannikin and bring it up.”
Terrified as I was, I could not help thinking to myself that this must have been how Mr. Arrow got the strong waters that destroyed him.
Dick was gone but a little while, and during his absence Israel spoke straight on in the cook’s ear. It was but a word or two that I could catch, and yet I gathered some important news, for besides other scraps that tended to the same purpose, this whole clause was audible: “Not another man of them’ll jine.” Hence there were still faithful men on board.
When Dick returned, one after another of the trio took the pannikin and drank—one “To luck,” another with a “Here’s to old Flint,” and Silver himself saying, in a kind of song, “Here’s to ourselves, and hold your luff, plenty of prizes and plenty of duff.”
Just then a sort of brightness fell upon me in the barrel, and looking up, I found the moon had risen and was silvering the mizzen-top and shining white on the luff of the fore-sail; and almost at the same time the voice of the lookout shouted, “Land ho!”

events.title: Island Sighted and Silver's Cartographic Deception
detailed_summary: The narrator, Jim Hawkins, after hastily exiting the apple barrel, manages to join Hunter and Dr. Livesey on deck without being seen by those he was spying on, as everyone hurried towards the weather bow.

The timely lifting of a fog bank coincided with the moon's appearance, revealing two low hills to the south-west, approximately two miles apart, with a taller, fog-enshrouded peak rising behind one of them, all appearing conical.
Still reeling from his recent fear, Jim observed these sights as if in a dream.
Captain Smollett then gave commands, altering the Hispaniola's course to pass the island to its east.
The captain inquired if any of the crew recognized the newly sighted land.
Long John Silver stepped forward, claiming prior knowledge of the island from a time he was a cook on a trading vessel that had stopped there for water.

Silver confidently provided details, stating the anchorage was south, behind an islet, and that the island was called Skeleton Island, a former pirate hub. He identified the northern hill as Foremast Hill and a southern trio as fore, main, and mizzen, with the main, cloud-topped hill commonly known as the Spy-glass, used by pirates as a lookout.

Captain Smollett produced a chart, and Silver, though his eyes gleamed with interest, quickly perceived it was an accurate copy but lacked the crucial treasure markings from the original map found in Billy Bones's chest.

Despite his evident annoyance, Silver adeptly masked his disappointment, affirming the chart's accuracy, pointing out features like 'Capt. Kidd’s Anchorage,' and discussing currents, thereby substantiating his supposed familiarity and appearing cooperative.
Captain Smollett thanked Silver for the information, indicated he might seek his assistance later, and then dismissed him.

events.text_segment:
There was a great rush of feet across the deck. I could hear people tumbling up from the cabin and the forecastle, and slipping in an instant outside my barrel, I dived behind the fore-sail, made a double towards the stern, and came out upon the open deck in time to join Hunter and Dr. Livesey in the rush for the weather bow.
There all hands were already congregated. A belt of fog had lifted almost simultaneously with the appearance of the moon. Away to the south-west of us we saw two low hills, about a couple of miles apart, and rising behind one of them a third and higher hill, whose peak was still buried in the fog. All three seemed sharp and conical in figure.
So much I saw, almost in a dream, for I had not yet recovered from my horrid fear of a minute or two before. And then I heard the voice of Captain Smollett issuing orders. The Hispaniola was laid a couple of points nearer the wind and now sailed a course that would just clear the island on the east.
“And now, men,” said the captain, when all was sheeted home, “has any one of you ever seen that land ahead?”
“I have, sir,” said Silver. “I’ve watered there with a trader I was cook in.”
“The anchorage is on the south, behind an islet, I fancy?” asked the captain.
“Yes, sir; Skeleton Island they calls it. It were a main place for pirates once, and a hand we had on board knowed all their names for it. That hill to the nor’ard they calls the Foremast Hill; there are three hills in a row running south’ard—fore, main, and mizzen, sir. But the main—that’s the big un, with the cloud on it—they usually calls the Spy-glass, by reason of a lookout they kept when they was in the anchorage cleaning, for it’s there they cleaned their ships, sir, asking your pardon.”
“I have a chart here,” says Captain Smollett. “See if that’s the place.”
Long John’s eyes burned in his head as he took the chart, but by the fresh look of the paper I knew he was doomed to disappointment. This was not the map we found in Billy Bones’s chest, but an accurate copy, complete in all things—names and heights and soundings—with the single exception of the red crosses and the written notes. Sharp as must have been his annoyance, Silver had the strength of mind to hide it.
“Yes, sir,” said he, “this is the spot, to be sure, and very prettily drawed out. Who might have done that, I wonder? The pirates were too ignorant, I reckon. Aye, here it is: ‘Capt. Kidd’s Anchorage’—just the name my shipmate called it. There’s a strong current runs along the south, and then away nor’ard up the west coast. Right you was, sir,” says he, “to haul your wind and keep the weather of the island. Leastways, if such was your intention as to enter and careen, and there ain’t no better place for that in these waters.”
“Thank you, my man,” says Captain Smollett. “I’ll ask you later on to give us a help. You may go.”
