There the two watchmen were, just as expected: Red-cap on his back, rigid as a stiff board, with his arms spread out like a crucifix and his teeth showing through his open mouth; Israel Hands propped against the side railing, his chin on his chest, his hands lying open on the deck before him, his face as pale as a wax candle beneath its tan. For a time, the ship pitched and swayed uncontrollably like a wild horse, the sails filling first on one side, then the other, and the boom swinging back and forth until the mast groaned loudly under the stress. Occasionally, too, a burst of light spray would come over the side railing, followed by the ship's bow striking the swells heavily; this large, fully rigged ship struggled much more in the heavy weather than my simple, uneven little boat, now at the bottom of the sea. With each lurch of the schooner, Red-cap slid back and forth, but—horrifyingly—neither his posture nor his fixed, teeth-baring grin was disturbed in any way by this rough motion. With each jolt also, Hands seemed to settle further into himself and sink down onto the deck, his feet sliding increasingly outwards, and his entire body tilting towards the stern, so that his face was gradually hidden from my view; finally, I could see nothing but his ear and the frayed curl of one side-whisker. At the same time, I noticed splashes of dark blood on the planks around both of them and began to feel certain they had killed each other in their drunken fury.

The sudden movement nearly knocked me into the sea, so I wasted no time in scurrying back along the bowsprit and fell headfirst onto the deck. I found myself on the sheltered side of the forecastle, where the still full mainsail blocked my view of part of the rear deck. There was nobody in sight. The deck, not cleaned since the mutiny, showed many footprints, and there was a broken-necked bottle rolling around the scuppers as if it were alive. There I saw the two watchmen at last: one, Red-cap, lying flat on his back, rigid and with his arms stretched out like a crucifix, his teeth showing through his open mouth; the other, Israel Hands, slumped against the rails, head down, hands open on the deck, his face pale beneath its tan, almost candle-white. At the same time, I noticed dark stains of blood around both men on the deck and began to realize they had likely killed each other in a drunken rage.

events.title: A Wounded Mutineer's Plea
detailed_summary: During a brief calm, Israel Hands stirs, moaning and shifting, revealing he is still alive.
The sound of Hands's pain and weakness initially evokes sympathy in Jim.
However, Jim's pity vanishes when he recalls Hands's role in the mutiny, which he overheard from the apple barrel.
Jim approaches Hands and addresses him with irony.
Hands, too weak to show surprise or respond at length, simply requests “Brandy.”

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: While I was thus looking and wondering, in a calm moment, when the ship was still, Israel Hands turned partly round and with a low moan writhed himself back to the position in which I had seen him first.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: All he could do was to utter one word, “Brandy.”

events.text_segment:
While I was thus looking and wondering, in a calm moment, when the ship was still, Israel Hands turned partly round and with a low moan writhed himself back to the position in which I had seen him first. The moan, which told of pain and deadly weakness, and the way in which his jaw hung open went right to my heart. But when I remembered the talk I had overheard from the apple barrel, all pity left me.
I walked aft until I reached the main-mast.
“Come aboard, Mr. Hands,” I said ironically.
He rolled his eyes round heavily, but he was too far gone to express surprise. All he could do was to utter one word, “Brandy.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: As I was watching and contemplating during a calm period when the ship was still, Israel Hands turned slightly and, with a soft groan, twisted himself back into the posture where I had initially seen him. The moan, which conveyed his pain and extreme frailty, and the way his jaw hung loose deeply affected me. Yet, when I brought to mind the conversation I had overheard from inside the apple barrel, all feelings of pity for him disappeared. I walked towards the back of the vessel until I reached the main mast. "Welcome aboard, Mr. Hands," I said, my tone heavy with irony. He slowly rolled his eyes, but he was too weak and injured to show any surprise. The only thing he could manage to say was a single word: "Brandy."

I moved toward the main-mast. "Come aboard, Mr. Hands," I said with mocking irony. He slowly turned his gaze toward me, but he was so weak that he couldn’t show any reaction except to murmur a single word: "Brandy."

events.title: Foraging Amidst Cabin Chaos
detailed_summary: Recognizing the need for haste, Jim carefully navigates the unstable deck to reach the ship's cabin.
He discovers the cabin in a state of utter confusion, with locked compartments broken into, presumably in search of the chart.
The floor is caked with mud from the mutineers' boots, the white bulkheads are smeared with dirty handprints, and empty bottles clink in the corners.
A medical book belonging to the doctor lies open and damaged, its pages likely torn out for lighting pipes.
Jim proceeds to the cellar, finding all the barrels gone and a surprising number of bottles emptied and discarded, indicating constant drunkenness among the mutineers.
He successfully locates a bottle containing some brandy for Hands.
For himself, he gathers biscuits, pickled fruits, raisins, and a piece of cheese.
Returning to the deck, Jim secures his own supplies, takes a drink of water, and only then gives the brandy to Hands.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: With these I came on deck, put down my own stock behind the rudder head and well out of the coxswain’s reach, went forward to the water-breaker, and had a good deep drink of water, and then, and not till then, gave Hands the brandy.

events.text_segment:
It occurred to me there was no time to lose, and dodging the boom as it once more lurched across the deck, I slipped aft and down the companion stairs into the cabin.
It was such a scene of confusion as you can hardly fancy. All the lockfast places had been broken open in quest of the chart. The floor was thick with mud where ruffians had sat down to drink or consult after wading in the marshes round their camp. The bulkheads, all painted in clear white and beaded round with gilt, bore a pattern of dirty hands. Dozens of empty bottles clinked together in corners to the rolling of the ship. One of the doctor’s medical books lay open on the table, half of the leaves gutted out, I suppose, for pipelights. In the midst of all this the lamp still cast a smoky glow, obscure and brown as umber.
I went into the cellar; all the barrels were gone, and of the bottles a most surprising number had been drunk out and thrown away. Certainly, since the mutiny began, not a man of them could ever have been sober.
Foraging about, I found a bottle with some brandy left, for Hands; and for myself I routed out some biscuit, some pickled fruits, a great bunch of raisins, and a piece of cheese. With these I came on deck, put down my own stock behind the rudder head and well out of the coxswain’s reach, went forward to the water-breaker, and had a good deep drink of water, and then, and not till then, gave Hands the brandy.

The cabin was in a state of confusion that is hard to imagine. Everything that could be locked had been broken open during the search for the chart. The floor was covered with thick mud where the ruffians had sat to drink or talk after wading through the marshes surrounding their camp. The walls, which were painted a clean white and bordered with gold, were marked with dirty handprints. As the ship rolled, dozens of empty bottles rattled together in the corners. One of the doctor’s medical books lay open on the table, with half of its pages, I presumed, ripped out for lighting pipes. Through all this, the lamp still gave off a smoky light, dim and brownish like umber. I went into the cellar; all the barrels were gone, and a surprisingly large number of bottles had been emptied and discarded. It was evident that not a single one of them could have been sober since the mutiny began. Searching around, I found a bottle with a bit of brandy left, intended for Hands; and for myself, I managed to find some biscuit, some preserved fruits, a large bunch of raisins, and a piece of cheese. Taking these items, I returned to the deck, placed my own provisions behind the top of the rudder, safely out of the coxswain’s reach, then went forward to the water container for a good, deep drink of water. After that, and not before, I gave the brandy to Hands.

events.title: Asserting Command and Defying Mutiny
detailed_summary: Israel Hands greedily drinks a substantial amount of the brandy Jim provides.
Jim, having begun to eat his own food, asks Hands about the severity of his injuries.
Hands responds with a grunt, wishing the doctor were present and lamenting his ill fortune.
He confirms the death of the other watchman (O'Brien, the man in the red cap), disparaging his seamanship.
Hands then questions Jim about his presence on the ship.
Jim boldly declares that he has come aboard to assume command and instructs Hands to consider him captain.
Hands gives Jim a sour look but remains silent, some color returning to his face, though he still appears very ill and continues to shift with the ship's movements.
Jim announces his refusal to sail under the pirates' flag and states his intention to remove it.
He dodges the swinging boom, lowers the pirates' black flag, and throws it into the sea, exclaiming loyalty to the king and the end of Captain Silver's reign.
Throughout this, Hands observes Jim with a sharp, cunning, and watchful expression.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He must have drunk a gill before he took the bottle from his mouth.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He watched me keenly and slyly, his chin all the while on his breast.

events.text_segment:
He must have drunk a gill before he took the bottle from his mouth.
“Aye,” said he, “by thunder, but I wanted some o’ that!”
I had sat down already in my own corner and begun to eat.
“Much hurt?” I asked him.
He grunted, or rather, I might say, he barked.
“If that doctor was aboard,” he said, “I’d be right enough in a couple of turns, but I don’t have no manner of luck, you see, and that’s what’s the matter with me. As for that swab, he’s good and dead, he is,” he added, indicating the man with the red cap. “He warn’t no seaman anyhow. And where mought you have come from?”
“Well,” said I, “I’ve come aboard to take possession of this ship, Mr. Hands; and you’ll please regard me as your captain until further notice.”
He looked at me sourly enough but said nothing. Some of the colour had come back into his cheeks, though he still looked very sick and still continued to slip out and settle down as the ship banged about.
“By the by,” I continued, “I can’t have these colours, Mr. Hands; and by your leave, I’ll strike ’em. Better none than these.”
And again dodging the boom, I ran to the colour lines, handed down their cursed black flag, and chucked it overboard.
“God save the king!” said I, waving my cap. “And there’s an end to Captain Silver!”
He watched me keenly and slyly, his chin all the while on his breast.

"If the doctor were on board," he said, "I'd recover in no time, but as you see, I have absolutely no luck, and that's my problem. As for that wretch," he added, indicating the man with the red cap, "he's definitely dead. He wasn't a sailor anyway." He then asked, "And where did you come from?" "Well," I replied, "I've come aboard to take control of this ship, Mr. Hands; and please regard me as your captain from now on." He looked at me with considerable displeasure but said nothing. Some color had returned to his face, although he still looked very unwell and continued to slide and sink down as the ship tossed about. "Incidentally," I continued, "I cannot have these flags, Mr. Hands; with your permission, I'll take them down. No flag is better than these." Avoiding the boom again, I ran to the flag ropes, pulled down their hateful black flag, and tossed it into the sea. "God save the king!" I shouted, waving my cap. events.title: An Uneasy Bargain Struck
detailed_summary: Israel Hands, addressing Jim as 'Cap'n Hawkins,' proposes they discuss how Jim can get ashore.
Jim readily agrees to talk, and Hands begins to explain their situation.
Hands indicates the corpse of O'Brien, explaining they had intended to sail the Hispaniola back together.
With O'Brien dead, Hands admits he cannot manage the ship alone and implies Jim also lacks the skill to do so without his help.
He offers a deal: if Jim provides him with food, drink, and a bandage for his wound, Hands will teach him how to sail the ship.
Jim agrees to the terms but stipulates that their destination will be North Inlet, where he plans to beach the ship, not Captain Kidd's anchorage.
Hands, appearing to accept his defeat and limited options, readily concurs, stating he'd help Jim sail even to Execution Dock.
Jim finds the proposal sensible, and they formalize their agreement immediately.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I reckon,” he said at last, “I reckon, Cap’n Hawkins, you’ll kind of want to get ashore now. S’pose we talks.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Well, as it seemed to me, there was some sense in this. We struck our bargain on the spot.

events.text_segment:
“I reckon,” he said at last, “I reckon, Cap’n Hawkins, you’ll kind of want to get ashore now. S’pose we talks.”
“Why, yes,” says I, “with all my heart, Mr. Hands. Say on.” And I went back to my meal with a good appetite.
“This man,” he began, nodding feebly at the corpse “—O’Brien were his name, a rank Irelander—this man and me got the canvas on her, meaning for to sail her back. Well, he’s dead now, he is—as dead as bilge; and who’s to sail this ship, I don’t see. Without I gives you a hint, you ain’t that man, as far’s I can tell. Now, look here, you gives me food and drink and a old scarf or ankecher to tie my wound up, you do, and I’ll tell you how to sail her, and that’s about square all round, I take it.”
“I’ll tell you one thing,” says I: “I’m not going back to Captain Kidd’s anchorage. I mean to get into North Inlet and beach her quietly there.”
“To be sure you did,” he cried. “Why, I ain’t sich an infernal lubber after all. I can see, can’t I? I’ve tried my fling, I have, and I’ve lost, and it’s you has the wind of me. North Inlet? Why, I haven’t no ch’ice, not I! I’d help you sail her up to Execution Dock, by thunder! So I would.”
Well, as it seemed to me, there was some sense in this. We struck our bargain on the spot.

Please go on.” Then I went back to my meal, eating heartily. Hands started, nodding weakly towards the dead body, “This man”—O’Brien was his name, an Irishman— “this man and I got the sails up, planning to sail her back. Well, he’s dead now, utterly dead; and I don’t see who’s going to sail this ship. Unless I give you instructions, you certainly aren’t the man, as far as I can tell. Now, listen, if you give me food, drink, and an old scarf or handkerchief to tie up my wound, I’ll tell you how to sail her, and I figure that’s a pretty fair exchange.” I said, “I’ll tell you one thing: I’m not going back to Captain Kidd’s hiding place. I plan to go into North Inlet and quietly wreck her there.” “Of course you did,” he shouted. “Why, I’m not such a complete idiot after all. I can see things, can’t I? I’ve tried my luck, I have, and I’ve lost, and you’re in control now. North Inlet? Why, I have absolutely no other option! I’d help you sail her right up to Execution Dock, by thunder! events.title: Setting Sail and Tending Wounds
detailed_summary: Very quickly, Jim gets the Hispaniola under sail, heading smoothly along the coast of Treasure Island towards North Inlet.
He aims to round the island's northern point by midday and reach North Inlet by high tide to safely beach the vessel.
After securing the tiller, Jim goes below deck to retrieve a soft silk handkerchief belonging to his mother.
He then assists Israel Hands in bandaging the severe stab wound on his thigh using the handkerchief.

Following this care, along with some food and more brandy, Hands shows marked signs of improvement: he sits more upright, his voice becomes stronger and clearer, and his overall appearance seems transformed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: In three minutes I had the Hispaniola sailing easily before the wind along the coast of Treasure Island, with good hopes of turning the northern point ere noon and beating down again as far as North Inlet before high water, when we might beach her safely and wait till the subsiding tide permitted us to land.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: With this, and with my aid, Hands bound up the great bleeding stab he had received in the thigh, and after he had eaten a little and had a swallow or two more of the brandy, he began to pick up visibly, sat straighter up, spoke louder and clearer, and looked in every way another man.

events.text_segment:
In three minutes I had the Hispaniola sailing easily before the wind along the coast of Treasure Island, with good hopes of turning the northern point ere noon and beating down again as far as North Inlet before high water, when we might beach her safely and wait till the subsiding tide permitted us to land.
Then I lashed the tiller and went below to my own chest, where I got a soft silk handkerchief of my mother’s. With this, and with my aid, Hands bound up the great bleeding stab he had received in the thigh, and after he had eaten a little and had a swallow or two more of the brandy, he began to pick up visibly, sat straighter up, spoke louder and clearer, and looked in every way another man.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: In just three minutes, I had the Hispaniola smoothly navigating downwind along Treasure Island's shoreline. I was hopeful we would pass the northernmost point before noon and then sail back toward North Inlet ahead of the high tide, enabling us to safely run her aground there and wait for the water level to drop so we could get ashore. Afterward, I secured the tiller and went below to find my personal chest, from which I took a soft silk handkerchief of my mother's. With this cloth and my help, Hands was able to bandage the significant, profusely bleeding stab wound he had sustained in his thigh. After he had eaten a little and had a few more sips of brandy, he started to recover noticeably, sitting up straighter, speaking with greater volume and clarity, and appearing completely revitalized.

Once he had eaten a little and taken another sip or two of brandy, he quickly recovered, sat more upright, spoke with more energy and clarity, and generally seemed like a completely different person.

events.title: Elation and Lingering Distrust
detailed_summary: A favorable wind allows the Hispaniola to travel swiftly, offering rapidly changing views of the island's coast.
They sail past high lands, then a low, sandy stretch dotted with pines, and finally navigate around the rocky northern extremity of the island.
Jim feels a great sense of exhilaration from his new command, the pleasant weather, and the scenic journey.
With plenty of supplies and the success of his actions, the guilt he felt for his earlier desertion subsides.
His satisfaction is, however, disturbed by the constant, derisive gaze of Israel Hands.
Hands's smile, though showing pain and weakness, also contains an element of mockery and an unnerving hint of treachery as he continuously and craftily observes Jim.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The breeze served us admirably.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was a smile that had in it something both of pain and weakness—a haggard old man’s smile; but there was, besides that, a grain of derision, a shadow of treachery, in his expression as he craftily watched, and watched, and watched me at my work.

events.text_segment:
The breeze served us admirably. We skimmed before it like a bird, the coast of the island flashing by and the view changing every minute. Soon we were past the high lands and bowling beside low, sandy country, sparsely dotted with dwarf pines, and soon we were beyond that again and had turned the corner of the rocky hill that ends the island on the north.
I was greatly elated with my new command, and pleased with the bright, sunshiny weather and these different prospects of the coast. I had now plenty of water and good things to eat, and my conscience, which had smitten me hard for my desertion, was quieted by the great conquest I had made. I should, I think, have had nothing left me to desire but for the eyes of the coxswain as they followed me derisively about the deck and the odd smile that appeared continually on his face. It was a smile that had in it something both of pain and weakness—a haggard old man’s smile; but there was, besides that, a grain of derision, a shadow of treachery, in his expression as he craftily watched, and watched, and watched me at my work.

We moved rapidly across the water, much like a bird in flight, with the island's edge sweeping past quickly and the scenery transforming constantly. Before long, we were past the elevated terrain, sailing alongside a low, sandy stretch of land thinly populated with small pine trees. Soon after passing that, we rounded the bend of the rocky hill that marks the northern extremity of the island. I was extremely happy about being in command and enjoyed the bright, sunny conditions and the varied views of the coastline. I had sufficient water and good food now, and my guilt, which had bothered me greatly for leaving the others, was relieved by the significant achievement I had made. I think I would have felt completely satisfied, were it not for the coxswain's gaze following me around the deck with contempt and the strange smile that remained on his face. It was a smile that contained elements of both suffering and frailty—the smile of a weary old man; however, beyond that, there was a trace of scorn, a hint of betrayal, in his expression as he shrewdly observed me while I worked.

events.title: Uneasy Truce and a Suspicious Request
detailed_summary: With a favorable wind, Jim and Hands found themselves waiting for the tide to rise sufficiently to beach the Hispaniola, as they couldn't anchor.
Jim successfully managed to lay the ship to after several attempts, as instructed by Hands, and they shared another meal in silence.
Hands, with an unsettling smile, suggested that Jim should dispose of O'Brien's corpse, claiming it was unsightly.
Jim refused, stating he lacked the strength and inclination for the task.
Hands lamented the bad luck of the Hispaniola and the many deaths, then curiously asked Jim if dead men truly stay dead or if they can return.
Jim affirmed that the body can be killed but not the spirit, suggesting O'Brien might be observing them from another world.
Hands found this idea unfortunate, deeming killing a waste if spirits persist, but ultimately decided to disregard spirits.
He then asked Jim to fetch him a bottle of wine from the cabin, pretending that the brandy was too potent for him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The wind, serving us to a desire, now hauled into the west.

Only, as we had no power to anchor and dared not beach her till the tide had flowed a good deal farther, time hung on our hands. The coxswain told me how to lay the ship to; after a good many trials I succeeded, and we both sat in silence over another meal.
“Cap’n,” said he at length with that same uncomfortable smile, “here’s my old shipmate, O’Brien; s’pose you was to heave him overboard. I ain’t partic’lar as a rule, and I don’t take no blame for settling his hash, but I don’t reckon him ornamental now, do you?”

events.title: Jim's Suspicions Confirmed: Hands Retrieves a Hidden Dirk
detailed_summary: Jim immediately sensed that Hands' reluctance and preference for wine over brandy were feigned; the entire request was a ruse.
He understood Hands wanted him off the deck but couldn't discern the exact motive.
Hands avoided eye contact, his gaze shifting around and occasionally falling on O'Brien's body, all while smiling guiltily and sticking his tongue out in an obviously deceptive manner.
Jim, seeing his advantage with such an unintelligent conspirator, quickly agreed to fetch wine, planning to conceal his suspicions.
He asked Hands if he preferred white or red wine.
Hands replied indifferently, caring only that the wine was strong and plentiful.
Jim announced he would bring port but claimed he would need to search for it.

He then went down the companionway noisily, removed his shoes, quietly moved along the gallery, ascended the forecastle ladder, and peered out of the fore companion, anticipating Hands would not expect him there.
His worst fears were confirmed: Hands, despite his injured leg causing him pain, dragged himself across the deck.
Within moments, Hands reached the port scuppers and retrieved a long, blood-stained knife or short dirk from a coil of rope.
He examined the weapon, tested its point on his hand, and then quickly hid it in his jacket before returning to his previous spot.
Jim now knew that Hands could move, was armed, and intended to make Jim his victim, though Hands' subsequent plans remained unclear.

events.text_segment:
Now, the coxswain’s hesitation seemed to be unnatural, and as for the notion of his preferring wine to brandy, I entirely disbelieved it. The whole story was a pretext. He wanted me to leave the deck—so much was plain; but with what purpose I could in no way imagine. His eyes never met mine; they kept wandering to and fro, up and down, now with a look to the sky, now with a flitting glance upon the dead O’Brien. All the time he kept smiling and putting his tongue out in the most guilty, embarrassed manner, so that a child could have told that he was bent on some deception. I was prompt with my answer, however, for I saw where my advantage lay and that with a fellow so densely stupid I could easily conceal my suspicions to the end.
“Some wine?” I said. “Far better. Will you have white or red?”
“Well, I reckon it’s about the blessed same to me, shipmate,” he replied; “so it’s strong, and plenty of it, what’s the odds?”
“All right,” I answered. “I’ll bring you port, Mr. Hands. But I’ll have to dig for it.”
With that I scuttled down the companion with all the noise I could, slipped off my shoes, ran quietly along the sparred gallery, mounted the forecastle ladder, and popped my head out of the fore companion. I knew he would not expect to see me there, yet I took every precaution possible, and certainly the worst of my suspicions proved too true.
He had risen from his position to his hands and knees, and though his leg obviously hurt him pretty sharply when he moved—for I could hear him stifle a groan—yet it was at a good, rattling rate that he trailed himself across the deck. In half a minute he had reached the port scuppers and picked, out of a coil of rope, a long knife, or rather a short dirk, discoloured to the hilt with blood. He looked upon it for a moment, thrusting forth his under jaw, tried the point upon his hand, and then, hastily concealing it in the bosom of his jacket, trundled back again into his old place against the bulwark.
This was all that I required to know. Israel could move about, he was now armed, and if he had been at so much trouble to get rid of me, it was plain that I was meant to be the victim. What he would do afterwards—whether he would try to crawl right across the island from North Inlet to the camp among the swamps or whether he would fire Long Tom, trusting that his own comrades might come first to help him—was, of course, more than I could say.

detailed_summary: Jim believed Hands wouldn't harm him until the schooner was safely stranded in a sheltered location, as this was a shared goal, allowing for her future retrieval.

Hands was positioned as Jim had left him, appearing weak with his eyelids lowered.

He added dramatically that this would likely be his last quid, as he felt he was dying.

Yet I felt sure that I could trust him in one point, since in that our interests jumped together, and that was in the disposition of the schooner. We both desired to have her stranded safe enough, in a sheltered place, and so that, when the time came, she could be got off again with as little labour and danger as might be; and until that was done I considered that my life would certainly be spared.
While I was thus turning the business over in my mind, I had not been idle with my body. I had stolen back to the cabin, slipped once more into my shoes, and laid my hand at random on a bottle of wine, and now, with this for an excuse, I made my reappearance on the deck.
Hands lay as I had left him, all fallen together in a bundle and with his eyelids lowered as though he were too weak to bear the light. He looked up, however, at my coming, knocked the neck off the bottle like a man who had done the same thing often, and took a good swig, with his favourite toast of “Here’s luck!” Then he lay quiet for a little, and then, pulling out a stick of tobacco, begged me to cut him a quid.

events.title: Moral Confrontation and Hands' Cynical Philosophy
detailed_summary: Jim agreed to cut the tobacco but advised Hands that if he truly felt so ill, he should pray like a Christian.
Hands questioned Jim's reasoning.

Jim, with some anger and thinking of the concealed dirk, reminded Hands of his past treachery, sins, and the man he had killed (O'Brien) lying at his feet, stating these were reasons for seeking God's mercy.
Hands took another large swig of wine and spoke with unusual gravity.
He declared that in his thirty years at sea, through all manner of experiences, he had never seen any good result from being good.
He stated his preference for striking first and his belief that dead men cannot cause harm, concluding with an "amen."

Abruptly shifting his tone, Hands declared an end to their current idleness, announced the tide was favorable, and ordered Jim, as 'Cap'n Hawkins', to take his commands to sail the ship into the inlet.

“Well,” said I, “I’ll cut you some tobacco, but if I was you and thought myself so badly, I would go to my prayers like a Christian man.”
“Why?” said he. “Now, you tell me why.”
“Why?” I cried. “You were asking me just now about the dead. You’ve broken your trust; you’ve lived in sin and lies and blood; there’s a man you killed lying at your feet this moment, and you ask me why! For God’s mercy, Mr. Hands, that’s why.”
I spoke with a little heat, thinking of the bloody dirk he had hidden in his pocket and designed, in his ill thoughts, to end me with. He, for his part, took a great draught of the wine and spoke with the most unusual solemnity.
“For thirty years,” he said, “I’ve sailed the seas and seen good and bad, better and worse, fair weather and foul, provisions running out, knives going, and what not. Well, now I tell you, I never seen good come o’ goodness yet. Him as strikes first is my fancy; dead men don’t bite; them’s my views—amen, so be it. And now, you look here,” he added, suddenly changing his tone, “we’ve had about enough of this foolery. The tide’s made good enough by now. You just take my orders, Cap’n Hawkins, and we’ll sail slap in and be done with it.”

events.title: Navigating the Treacherous Inlet to Beach the Hispaniola
detailed_summary: They had less than two miles to cover, but the passage into the northern anchorage was challenging, being narrow, shallow, and oriented east-west, requiring skillful maneuvering.
Jim acted as a competent subordinate while Hands proved an excellent pilot, guiding the ship with precision close to the banks.
Once past the headlands, the land enclosed them; the shores of North Inlet were densely wooded, the space longer, narrower, and river-like.
Ahead, at the southern end, they saw the dilapidated wreck of a large, three-masted ship, covered in seaweed and flourishing bushes, which signaled a calm anchorage.
Hands pointed out a perfect spot to beach the ship, describing it as having flat sand, shelter from wind, surrounding trees, and flowers blooming on the old wreck.
When Jim asked how they would refloat the ship later, Hands explained a method involving a line taken ashore to a pine, then to the capstan, to be hauled when the tide was high.
As they neared the chosen spot with too much momentum, Hands issued rapid steering commands: "Starboard a little—so—steady—starboard—larboard a little—steady—steady!"
Finally, Hands shouted for Jim to "luff," and Jim put the helm hard over, causing the Hispaniola to turn sharply and head directly for the shore.

events.text_segment:
All told, we had scarce two miles to run; but the navigation was delicate, the entrance to this northern anchorage was not only narrow and shoal, but lay east and west, so that the schooner must be nicely handled to be got in. I think I was a good, prompt subaltern, and I am very sure that Hands was an excellent pilot, for we went about and about and dodged in, shaving the banks, with a certainty and a neatness that were a pleasure to behold.
Scarcely had we passed the heads before the land closed around us. The shores of North Inlet were as thickly wooded as those of the southern anchorage, but the space was longer and narrower and more like, what in truth it was, the estuary of a river. Right before us, at the southern end, we saw the wreck of a ship in the last stages of dilapidation. It had been a great vessel of three masts but had lain so long exposed to the injuries of the weather that it was hung about with great webs of dripping seaweed, and on the deck of it shore bushes had taken root and now flourished thick with flowers. It was a sad sight, but it showed us that the anchorage was calm.
“Now,” said Hands, “look there; there’s a pet bit for to beach a ship in. Fine flat sand, never a cat’s paw, trees all around of it, and flowers a-blowing like a garding on that old ship.”
“And once beached,” I inquired, “how shall we get her off again?”
“Why, so,” he replied: “you take a line ashore there on the other side at low water, take a turn about one of them big pines; bring it back, take a turn around the capstan, and lie to for the tide. Come high water, all hands take a pull upon the line, and off she comes as sweet as natur’. And now, boy, you stand by. We’re near the bit now, and she’s too much way on her. Starboard a little—so—steady—starboard—larboard a little—steady—steady!”
So he issued his commands, which I breathlessly obeyed, till, all of a sudden, he cried, “Now, my hearty, luff!” And I put the helm hard up, and the Hispaniola swung round rapidly and ran stem on for the low, wooded shore.

events.title: Hands' Sudden Attack and Jim's Failed Pistol Shot
detailed_summary: The intensity of beaching the ship had distracted Jim from his vigilant watch over Hands.
He was so engrossed in waiting for the ship to touch ground, craning over the starboard bulwarks, that he had momentarily forgotten the danger he was in.
A sudden feeling of unease caused him to turn his head, perhaps hearing a sound or seeing a shadow.
Upon looking around, he saw Hands halfway towards him, brandishing the dirk in his right hand.
Both cried out simultaneously – Jim in terror, Hands with a furious roar.
As Hands lunged, Jim leaped sideways towards the bows, releasing the tiller.
The tiller swung sharply to leeward, striking Hands across the chest and stopping him momentarily, which Jim believed saved his life.
Before Hands could recover, Jim was out of the corner, drew a pistol, and took a cool aim, even as Hands turned and came after him again.
He pulled the trigger, but the pistol only clicked; the priming was wet from seawater, rendering it useless.
Jim cursed his own negligence for not having re-primed and reloaded his weapons earlier, which left him vulnerable.

The excitement of these last manoeuvres had somewhat interfered with the watch I had kept hitherto, sharply enough, upon the coxswain. Even then I was still so much interested, waiting for the ship to touch, that I had quite forgot the peril that hung over my head and stood craning over the starboard bulwarks and watching the ripples spreading wide before the bows. I might have fallen without a struggle for my life had not a sudden disquietude seized upon me and made me turn my head. Perhaps I had heard a creak or seen his shadow moving with the tail of my eye; perhaps it was an instinct like a cat’s; but, sure enough, when I looked round, there was Hands, already half-way towards me, with the dirk in his right hand.
We must both have cried out aloud when our eyes met, but while mine was the shrill cry of terror, his was a roar of fury like a charging bully’s. At the same instant, he threw himself forward and I leapt sideways towards the bows. As I did so, I let go of the tiller, which sprang sharp to leeward, and I think this saved my life, for it struck Hands across the chest and stopped him, for the moment, dead.
Before he could recover, I was safe out of the corner where he had me trapped, with all the deck to dodge about. Just forward of the main-mast I stopped, drew a pistol from my pocket, took a cool aim, though he had already turned and was once more coming directly after me, and drew the trigger. The hammer fell, but there followed neither flash nor sound; the priming was useless with sea-water. I cursed myself for my neglect. Why had not I, long before, reprimed and reloaded my only weapons? Then I should not have been as now, a mere fleeing sheep before this butcher.

events.title: A Desperate Game of Dodge and the Ship's Grounding
detailed_summary: Despite his injury, Hands moved with surprising speed, his face red with exertion and rage.
Jim had no time to try his other pistol and doubted its usefulness anyway.
He realized he couldn't simply retreat, or Hands would trap him in the bows as he had nearly done in the stern; such a capture would mean death by the dirk.
Jim positioned himself against the large main-mast, ready to dodge, every nerve taut.
Seeing Jim's intent, Hands also paused, leading to a brief period of feints and corresponding movements, like a childhood game but with terrifying stakes.
Jim's courage rose, thinking he could match the elderly, wounded seaman in this game, though he saw no ultimate means of escape.
Suddenly, the Hispaniola struck the sand, shuddered, and then sharply canted over to port, the deck tilting to a forty-five-degree angle, and water splashed into the scuppers.
Both Jim and Hands were instantly capsized and rolled into the scuppers, with the dead O'Brien's body tumbling stiffly after them.
They landed so close that Jim's head struck Hands' foot sharply.

events.text_segment:
Wounded as he was, it was wonderful how fast he could move, his grizzled hair tumbling over his face, and his face itself as red as a red ensign with his haste and fury. I had no time to try my other pistol, nor indeed much inclination, for I was sure it would be useless. One thing I saw plainly: I must not simply retreat before him, or he would speedily hold me boxed into the bows, as a moment since he had so nearly boxed me in the stern. Once so caught, and nine or ten inches of the blood-stained dirk would be my last experience on this side of eternity. I placed my palms against the main-mast, which was of a goodish bigness, and waited, every nerve upon the stretch.
Seeing that I meant to dodge, he also paused; and a moment or two passed in feints on his part and corresponding movements upon mine. It was such a game as I had often played at home about the rocks of Black Hill Cove, but never before, you may be sure, with such a wildly beating heart as now. Still, as I say, it was a boy’s game, and I thought I could hold my own at it against an elderly seaman with a wounded thigh. Indeed my courage had begun to rise so high that I allowed myself a few darting thoughts on what would be the end of the affair, and while I saw certainly that I could spin it out for long, I saw no hope of any ultimate escape.
Well, while things stood thus, suddenly the Hispaniola struck, staggered, ground for an instant in the sand, and then, swift as a blow, canted over to the port side till the deck stood at an angle of forty-five degrees and about a puncheon of water splashed into the scupper holes and lay, in a pool, between the deck and bulwark.
We were both of us capsized in a second, and both of us rolled, almost together, into the scuppers, the dead red-cap, with his arms still spread out, tumbling stiffly after us. So near were we, indeed, that my head came against the coxswain’s foot with a crack that made my teeth rattle.

detailed_summary: Despite the impact, Jim was the first to regain his footing, as Hands had become entangled with O'Brien's corpse.
The steeply tilted deck made running impossible, forcing Jim to find a new escape route immediately, with Hands almost upon him.
Reacting instantly, Jim leaped into the mizzen shrouds and climbed rapidly, not pausing until he reached the cross-trees.
His prompt action saved him; the dirk struck the mast just below his feet as he ascended.
Israel Hands stood below, mouth open, face upturned in a perfect expression of surprise and disappointment.
Taking advantage of the moment, Jim quickly changed the priming of one pistol and then reloaded the other completely to ensure he was well-armed.
Jim's rearming efforts seemed to stun Hands, who realized the situation was turning against him.
After some hesitation, Hands also began to climb the shrouds, holding the dirk in his teeth, moving slowly and painfully due to his wounded leg.
Jim had finished preparing his pistols before Hands was even a third of the way up.

events.text_segment:
Blow and all, I was the first afoot again, for Hands had got involved with the dead body. The sudden canting of the ship had made the deck no place for running on; I had to find some new way of escape, and that upon the instant, for my foe was almost touching me. Quick as thought, I sprang into the mizzen shrouds, rattled up hand over hand, and did not draw a breath till I was seated on the cross-trees.
I had been saved by being prompt; the dirk had struck not half a foot below me as I pursued my upward flight; and there stood Israel Hands with his mouth open and his face upturned to mine, a perfect statue of surprise and disappointment.
Now that I had a moment to myself, I lost no time in changing the priming of my pistol, and then, having one ready for service, and to make assurance doubly sure, I proceeded to draw the load of the other and recharge it afresh from the beginning.
My new employment struck Hands all of a heap; he began to see the dice going against him, and after an obvious hesitation, he also hauled himself heavily into the shrouds, and with the dirk in his teeth, began slowly and painfully to mount. It cost him no end of time and groans to haul his wounded leg behind him, and I had quietly finished my arrangements before he was much more than a third of the way up.

He stated that he and Jim were in a difficult situation ('fouled') and would have to come to an agreement ('sign articles').
Hands admitted that Jim would have been defeated if not for the ship's sudden lurch, attributing his failure to bad luck.
He concluded that he would have to surrender ('strike'), which he found humiliating for a master mariner to do before a young ship's boy like Jim.

Then, with a pistol in either hand, I addressed him.
“One more step, Mr. Hands,” said I, “and I’ll blow your brains out! Dead men don’t bite, you know,” I added with a chuckle.
He stopped instantly. I could see by the working of his face that he was trying to think, and the process was so slow and laborious that, in my new-found security, I laughed aloud. At last, with a swallow or two, he spoke, his face still wearing the same expression of extreme perplexity. In order to speak he had to take the dagger from his mouth, but in all else he remained unmoved.
“Jim,” says he, “I reckon we’re fouled, you and me, and we’ll have to sign articles. I’d have had you but for that there lurch, but I don’t have no luck, not I; and I reckon I’ll have to strike, which comes hard, you see, for a master mariner to a ship’s younker like you, Jim.”

events.title: Hands' Deceptive Attack and His Fatal Plunge
detailed_summary: Jim was complacently listening to Hands' words, feeling quite pleased with himself.
Suddenly, Hands swiftly brought his right hand back over his shoulder.
Something flew through the air like an arrow, and Jim felt a blow followed by a sharp pain; he found himself pinned by the shoulder to the mast by the dirk.
In the shock and agony of the moment, Jim's actions were almost involuntary and certainly unintentional; both his pistols discharged and fell from his grasp.
The pistols were not the only things to fall; with a choked cry, Hands lost his grip on the shrouds and plummeted headfirst into the water below.

events.title: Israel Hands's Demise and Jim's Traumatic Reaction
detailed_summary: From his position on the cross-trees, Jim observes Israel Hands, who was closer to the ship, fall into the water between him and the bulwarks.
Hands briefly resurfaces amidst foam and blood before sinking permanently.
Jim can see Hands's body settled on the bright sand beneath the ship, with fish darting past it and the water's movement creating an illusion of him trying to rise.
He confirms Hands is dead, both shot and drowned, ironically becoming food for fish in the very spot he intended to kill Jim.
A wave of nausea, faintness, and terror overwhelms Jim almost immediately after confirming Hands's death.

The physical pain from the dirk pinning his shoulder and his bleeding chest are less distressing to him than the profound horror of potentially falling from the cross-trees into the water beside Hands's corpse.
He grips the cross-trees until his nails ache and shuts his eyes against the perceived danger, eventually calming down and regaining his composure.

events.text_segment:
Owing to the cant of the vessel, the masts hung far out over the water, and from my perch on the cross-trees I had nothing below me but the surface of the bay. Hands, who was not so far up, was in consequence nearer to the ship and fell between me and the bulwarks. He rose once to the surface in a lather of foam and blood and then sank again for good. As the water settled, I could see him lying huddled together on the clean, bright sand in the shadow of the vessel’s sides. A fish or two whipped past his body. Sometimes, by the quivering of the water, he appeared to move a little, as if he were trying to rise. But he was dead enough, for all that, being both shot and drowned, and was food for fish in the very place where he had designed my slaughter.
I was no sooner certain of this than I began to feel sick, faint, and terrified. The hot blood was running over my back and chest. The dirk, where it had pinned my shoulder to the mast, seemed to burn like a hot iron; yet it was not so much these real sufferings that distressed me, for these, it seemed to me, I could bear without a murmur; it was the horror I had upon my mind of falling from the cross-trees into that still green water, beside the body of the coxswain.
I clung with both hands till my nails ached, and I shut my eyes as if to cover up the peril. Gradually my mind came back again, my pulses quieted down to a more natural time, and I was once more in possession of myself.

detailed_summary: Jim initially considers removing the dirk pinning his shoulder to the mast but lacks the nerve or strength, stopping with a shudder.
This very shudder, ironically, dislodges the knife, which had only superficially caught his skin.
Although the bleeding intensifies, Jim feels a renewed sense of control, now only attached to the mast by his coat and shirt.
He tears himself free with a sudden jerk and climbs back to the deck using the starboard shrouds, avoiding the port shrouds from which Hands had fallen.
Jim attends to his wound below deck, finding it painful and bleeding but neither deep nor dangerously impairing his arm's movement.
Considering the ship his own, he decides to remove its last remaining passenger, the deceased O'Brien.
He finds O'Brien's body slumped against the bulwarks, appearing like a grotesque puppet, and, having grown accustomed to such grim sights, disposes of it.
Jim takes O'Brien by the waist and heaves him overboard, where he lands with a splash, his red cap floating on the surface.
He then observes O'Brien's body lying beside Israel Hands's on the seabed, with fish swimming around both corpses.

events.text_segment:
It was my first thought to pluck forth the dirk, but either it stuck too hard or my nerve failed me, and I desisted with a violent shudder. Oddly enough, that very shudder did the business. The knife, in fact, had come the nearest in the world to missing me altogether; it held me by a mere pinch of skin, and this the shudder tore away. The blood ran down the faster, to be sure, but I was my own master again and only tacked to the mast by my coat and shirt.
These last I broke through with a sudden jerk, and then regained the deck by the starboard shrouds. For nothing in the world would I have again ventured, shaken as I was, upon the overhanging port shrouds from which Israel had so lately fallen.
I went below and did what I could for my wound; it pained me a good deal and still bled freely, but it was neither deep nor dangerous, nor did it greatly gall me when I used my arm. Then I looked around me, and as the ship was now, in a sense, my own, I began to think of clearing it from its last passenger—the dead man, O’Brien.
He had pitched, as I have said, against the bulwarks, where he lay like some horrible, ungainly sort of puppet, life-size, indeed, but how different from life’s colour or life’s comeliness! In that position I could easily have my way with him, and as the habit of tragical adventures had worn off almost all my terror for the dead, I took him by the waist as if he had been a sack of bran and with one good heave, tumbled him overboard. He went in with a sounding plunge; the red cap came off and remained floating on the surface; and as soon as the splash subsided, I could see him and Israel lying side by side, both wavering with the tremulous movement of the water. O’Brien, though still quite a young man, was very bald. There he lay, with that bald head across the knees of the man who had killed him and the quick fishes steering to and fro over both.

events.title: Securing and Abandoning the Hispaniola
detailed_summary: Jim finds himself the sole occupant of the Hispaniola as the tide begins to ebb and the setting sun casts long shadows across the deck.
The rising evening breeze causes the ship's rigging to hum and the sails to flap, signaling potential trouble for the vessel.
He successfully lowers and secures the jibs on deck but faces a greater challenge with the mainsail.
The ship's tilt has caused the boom to swing outboard, with part of the sail submerged, making it dangerous.
Despite his apprehension about the heavy strain, Jim uses his knife to cut the halyards, causing the mainsail's peak to drop and the canvas to spread across the water.
He is unable to manage the downhaul, leaving the Hispaniola to rely on luck, much like himself.
As the anchorage becomes fully shadowed, with the last sunbeams highlighting the wreck, the air grows chilly and the tide swiftly flows seaward, causing the schooner to list further.
Jim scrambles to the bow, assesses the water depth, and, holding the cut hawser for safety, drops overboard into waist-deep water.
He wades ashore onto firm sand with a sense of relief and accomplishment, leaving the Hispaniola on its side with its mainsail adrift as the sun sets completely.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I was now alone upon the ship; the tide had just turned.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: About the same time, the sun went fairly down and the breeze whistled low in the dusk among the tossing pines.

events.text_segment:
I was now alone upon the ship; the tide had just turned. The sun was within so few degrees of setting that already the shadow of the pines upon the western shore began to reach right across the anchorage and fall in patterns on the deck. The evening breeze had sprung up, and though it was well warded off by the hill with the two peaks upon the east, the cordage had begun to sing a little softly to itself and the idle sails to rattle to and fro.
I began to see a danger to the ship. The jibs I speedily doused and brought tumbling to the deck, but the main-sail was a harder matter. Of course, when the schooner canted over, the boom had swung out-board, and the cap of it and a foot or two of sail hung even under water. I thought this made it still more dangerous; yet the strain was so heavy that I half feared to meddle. At last I got my knife and cut the halyards. The peak dropped instantly, a great belly of loose canvas floated broad upon the water, and since, pull as I liked, I could not budge the downhall, that was the extent of what I could accomplish. For the rest, the Hispaniola must trust to luck, like myself.
By this time the whole anchorage had fallen into shadow—the last rays, I remember, falling through a glade of the wood and shining bright as jewels on the flowery mantle of the wreck. It began to be chill; the tide was rapidly fleeting seaward, the schooner settling more and more on her beam-ends.
I scrambled forward and looked over. It seemed shallow enough, and holding the cut hawser in both hands for a last security, I let myself drop softly overboard. The water scarcely reached my waist; the sand was firm and covered with ripple marks, and I waded ashore in great spirits, leaving the Hispaniola on her side, with her main-sail trailing wide upon the surface of the bay. About the same time, the sun went fairly down and the breeze whistled low in the dusk among the tossing pines.

I started to realize the ship was in danger. I quickly lowered the smaller front sails (the jibs), making them fall onto the deck, but the main sail was more challenging. Because the schooner was tilted over, the boom had swung outwards, with its end and a couple of feet of the sail submerged. I believed this made the situation even riskier; however, the strain was so intense that I was hesitant to interfere. Finally, I used my knife to cut the ropes that held the sail up (the halyards). The peak of the sail dropped instantly, a large bulk of loose canvas floated broadly on the water, and since I couldn't release the downhaul no matter how hard I pulled, that was all I managed to do. For the rest, the Hispaniola, like me, would have to rely on luck. By this time, the entire anchorage was cloaked in shadow—I remember the last rays of sunlight passing through a gap in the woods and shining brightly like gems on the flowery covering of the wreck. It started to feel cold; the tide was rapidly flowing out towards the sea, and the schooner was leaning more and more heavily onto its side. I climbed towards the front of the ship and looked over the edge. The water seemed quite shallow, and holding onto the cut anchor rope with both hands for final security, I gently lowered myself into the water. The water barely came up to my waist; the sand was firm and marked with ripples, and I waded towards the shore feeling very cheerful, leaving the Hispaniola tilted on its side with its large main sail trailing widely across the surface of the bay. Around the same moment, the sun completely set, and the breeze sighed softly in the twilight among the swaying pines.

events.title: Triumphant Return Ashore and a Puzzling Distant Fire
detailed_summary: Jim feels a profound sense of relief and pride at having escaped the sea and, more importantly, having reclaimed the Hispaniola from the pirates, making it ready for his own party.

His immediate desire is to return to the stockade and share news of his achievements, believing the recapture of the ship will excuse his unauthorized absence, perhaps even impressing Captain Smollett.
Filled with high spirits, he starts his journey towards the blockhouse and his companions.
He recalls that one of the rivers flowing into the anchorage originates from the two-peaked hill to his left and decides to follow its course upstream while it is still small.
The terrain is relatively open, and by following the lower hill spurs, he soon rounds the hill and wades across the stream.
This path brings him close to the area where he first encountered Ben Gunn, the maroon, prompting him to proceed with greater caution and vigilance.
As dusk settles, he notices a flickering glow against the sky near the cleft between the two peaks, which he assumes is Ben Gunn's campfire.
He privately wonders at Ben Gunn's apparent lack of caution, considering that the light from such a large fire could easily be spotted by Silver and his men camped nearby.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: For if I could see this radiance, might it not reach the eyes of Silver himself where he camped upon the shore among the marshes?

events.text_segment:
At least, and at last, I was off the sea, nor had I returned thence empty-handed. There lay the schooner, clear at last from buccaneers and ready for our own men to board and get to sea again. I had nothing nearer my fancy than to get home to the stockade and boast of my achievements. Possibly I might be blamed a bit for my truantry, but the recapture of the Hispaniola was a clenching answer, and I hoped that even Captain Smollett would confess I had not lost my time.
So thinking, and in famous spirits, I began to set my face homeward for the block house and my companions. I remembered that the most easterly of the rivers which drain into Captain Kidd’s anchorage ran from the two-peaked hill upon my left, and I bent my course in that direction that I might pass the stream while it was small. The wood was pretty open, and keeping along the lower spurs, I had soon turned the corner of that hill, and not long after waded to the mid-calf across the watercourse.
This brought me near to where I had encountered Ben Gunn, the maroon; and I walked more circumspectly, keeping an eye on every side. The dusk had come nigh hand completely, and as I opened out the cleft between the two peaks, I became aware of a wavering glow against the sky, where, as I judged, the man of the island was cooking his supper before a roaring fire. And yet I wondered, in my heart, that he should show himself so careless. For if I could see this radiance, might it not reach the eyes of Silver himself where he camped upon the shore among the marshes?

Finally, I was back on land, free from the sea, and I hadn't returned without success. The schooner lay anchored, at last clear of the pirates and ready for our own men to board and sail again. More than anything else, I wanted to get back to the stockade and tell everyone about my accomplishment. Perhaps I might face some reprimand for wandering off, but taking back the Hispaniola was a conclusive argument, and I hoped that even Captain Smollett would agree my time had been well spent.

Thinking this way and feeling very pleased, I started making my way back towards the blockhouse to rejoin my companions. I remembered that the most easterly river that flows into Captain Kidd's anchorage originated from the two-peaked hill to my left, and I angled my path in that direction so I could cross the stream while it was still small. The woods were fairly open, and by following the lower parts of the hillside, I soon rounded the corner of that hill and not long after waded through the stream, which only came up to my mid-calf.

This brought me near the place where I had met Ben Gunn, the man marooned on the island; as a result, I walked with greater caution, keeping a close watch on all sides. The twilight had almost completely settled, and as I moved through the opening between the two peaks, I became aware of a fluctuating light against the sky. I guessed that the island man was preparing his supper there over a large fire. Still, I was puzzled as to why he would display such carelessness. If I could see this radiance, might it not also be visible to Silver, who was camped near the shore among the marshes?

events.title: Navigating by Moonlight and Approaching a Mysterious Glow
detailed_summary: As the night grows darker, Jim struggles to maintain his course, with landmarks like the double hill and the Spy-glass becoming indistinct and stars providing little light.
He finds himself stumbling through bushes and into sandy pits in the low-lying terrain.
Suddenly, a brightness appears around him; he looks up to see pale moonlight illuminating the summit of the Spy-glass.
Shortly thereafter, he observes the moon itself, large and silvery, rising behind the trees.
With the moonlight to guide him, Jim moves more quickly over the remaining distance to the stockade, alternating between walking and running in his eagerness.
However, as he enters the grove leading to the stockade, he prudently slows his pace and proceeds with caution, wary of being accidentally shot by his own companions.
The rising moon casts patches of light through the trees, and directly ahead, Jim notices a glow of a different color—red and hot, resembling the embers of a dying bonfire.
He is completely baffled by the nature of this mysterious red glow.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: For the life of me I could not think what it might be.

events.text_segment:
Gradually the night fell blacker; it was all I could do to guide myself even roughly towards my destination; the double hill behind me and the Spy-glass on my right hand loomed faint and fainter; the stars were few and pale; and in the low ground where I wandered I kept tripping among bushes and rolling into sandy pits.
Suddenly a kind of brightness fell about me. I looked up; a pale glimmer of moonbeams had alighted on the summit of the Spy-glass, and soon after I saw something broad and silvery moving low down behind the trees, and knew the moon had risen.
With this to help me, I passed rapidly over what remained to me of my journey, and sometimes walking, sometimes running, impatiently drew near to the stockade. Yet, as I began to thread the grove that lies before it, I was not so thoughtless but that I slacked my pace and went a trifle warily. It would have been a poor end of my adventures to get shot down by my own party in mistake.
The moon was climbing higher and higher, its light began to fall here and there in masses through the more open districts of the wood, and right in front of me a glow of a different colour appeared among the trees. It was red and hot, and now and again it was a little darkened—as it were, the embers of a bonfire smouldering.
For the life of me I could not think what it might be.

Soon after, I saw a wide, silver glow moving low down behind the trees and knew the moon had risen. Aided by this light, I quickly completed the remainder of my trip, sometimes walking, sometimes running, anxiously approaching the stockade. It was red and warm, and every now and then, it would get a bit darker—like the banked coals of a large fire. For the life of me, I couldn't fathom what it might be.

events.title: Investigating the Eerily Silent Stockade
detailed_summary: Jim finally arrives at the edge of the clearing where the stockade is located.
He observes that the western part of the clearing is bathed in moonlight, while the rest, including the blockhouse itself, remains in deep shadow interspersed with silvery light streaks.
On the far side of the house, an enormous fire has burned down to clear embers, emitting a steady, red glow that contrasts sharply with the soft moonlight.
There is no sign of movement or any sound apart from the sighing of the breeze.
A mix of profound wonder and a touch of terror fills Jim, as building such large fires was contrary to their usual practice under Captain Smollett's orders to conserve firewood.
He begins to fear that something unfortunate occurred during his time away from the stockade.
Maintaining stealth, Jim circles around to the eastern side of the stockade, staying within the shadows, and finds a suitably dark spot to cross the defensive palisade.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At last I came right down upon the borders of the clearing.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I stole round by the eastern end, keeping close in shadow, and at a convenient place, where the darkness was thickest, crossed the palisade.

events.text_segment:
At last I came right down upon the borders of the clearing. The western end was already steeped in moonshine; the rest, and the block house itself, still lay in a black shadow chequered with long silvery streaks of light. On the other side of the house an immense fire had burned itself into clear embers and shed a steady, red reverberation, contrasted strongly with the mellow paleness of the moon. There was not a soul stirring nor a sound beside the noises of the breeze.
I stopped, with much wonder in my heart, and perhaps a little terror also. It had not been our way to build great fires; we were, indeed, by the captain’s orders, somewhat niggardly of firewood, and I began to fear that something had gone wrong while I was absent.
I stole round by the eastern end, keeping close in shadow, and at a convenient place, where the darkness was thickest, crossed the palisade.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Upon finally reaching the edge of the clearing, I saw that the western part was already bathed in moonlight, while the rest, along with the blockhouse itself, was still submerged in deep shadow, crossed by long, silvery shafts of light. Beyond the house, a large fire had dwindled to bright embers, casting a constant red glow that presented a strong contrast to the moon's soft paleness. The only sounds were those of the breeze; not a single person or creature stirred. I stopped, filled with considerable surprise and perhaps a touch of fear. Building such large fires wasn't our standard practice; under the captain's instructions, we were quite conservative with our firewood. This made me suspect that something unfortunate had occurred while I was away. I stealthily circled around the eastern end, keeping close to the shadows, and found a convenient spot where the darkness was deepest to cross the palisade.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Finally, I reached the edge of the clearing. The western side was already bathed in moonlight, while the rest, along with the blockhouse, remained in deep shadow interrupted by streaks of silvery light. Across from the blockhouse, a large fire had burned down to glowing embers, giving off a steady red glow that stood out against the gentle, pale light of the moon. Everything was silent and still, except for the sounds of the wind. Filled with curiosity and a bit of fear, I paused. We had never built such large fires before; in fact, following the captain's orders, we had been careful not to use much firewood. I began to worry that something might have happened during my absence. Keeping to the shadows, I crept around the eastern side and, where the darkness was deepest, crossed over the palisade.

events.title: False Reassurance and Parrot's Startling Alarm
detailed_summary: To ensure his safety and assess the situation, Jim cautiously crawls on his hands and knees towards a corner of the blockhouse.
His anxiety lessens significantly when he hears the sound of loud, peaceful snoring from within, which he interprets as his friends sleeping soundly.
He notes the irony that the watch's reassuring call of "All's well" had never sounded more welcome, despite the current circumstances.

He reflects on the poor quality of their watch, thinking that if Silver and his men had been approaching, they would have been easily overcome, and he blames himself for leaving his companions so vulnerable, especially with the captain injured.
Reaching the door, Jim stands up and enters the completely dark interior, unable to discern anything visually.
He hears the continuous drone of snores and a faint, inexplicable flickering or pecking sound.
He silently chuckles at the thought of lying down in his usual spot and enjoying his friends' surprise when they discover him in the morning.
His foot then makes contact with something soft – a sleeper's leg – causing the person to groan but not awaken.
Suddenly, a shrill voice erupts from the darkness, repeatedly squawking "Pieces of eight!", identified by Jim as Silver's parrot, Captain Flint.
Jim realizes the pecking sound he heard was the parrot, who, unlike the human occupants, was alert and now announcing his arrival.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: To make assurance surer, I got upon my hands and knees and crawled, without a sound, towards the corner of the house.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was she whom I had heard pecking at a piece of bark; it was she, keeping better watch than any human being, who thus announced my arrival with her wearisome refrain.

events.text_segment:
To make assurance surer, I got upon my hands and knees and crawled, without a sound, towards the corner of the house. As I drew nearer, my heart was suddenly and greatly lightened. It is not a pleasant noise in itself, and I have often complained of it at other times, but just then it was like music to hear my friends snoring together so loud and peaceful in their sleep. The sea-cry of the watch, that beautiful “All’s well,” never fell more reassuringly on my ear.
In the meantime, there was no doubt of one thing; they kept an infamous bad watch. If it had been Silver and his lads that were now creeping in on them, not a soul would have seen daybreak. That was what it was, thought I, to have the captain wounded; and again I blamed myself sharply for leaving them in that danger with so few to mount guard.
By this time I had got to the door and stood up. All was dark within, so that I could distinguish nothing by the eye. As for sounds, there was the steady drone of the snorers and a small occasional noise, a flickering or pecking that I could in no way account for.
With my arms before me I walked steadily in. I should lie down in my own place (I thought with a silent chuckle) and enjoy their faces when they found me in the morning.
My foot struck something yielding—it was a sleeper’s leg; and he turned and groaned, but without awaking.
And then, all of a sudden, a shrill voice broke forth out of the darkness:
“Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight!” and so forth, without pause or change, like the clacking of a tiny mill.
Silver’s green parrot, Captain Flint! It was she whom I had heard pecking at a piece of bark; it was she, keeping better watch than any human being, who thus announced my arrival with her wearisome refrain.

This second person seizes him firmly, preventing his escape.
Once Jim's capture is confirmed, Silver issues an order to someone named Dick, instructing him to bring a torch.
One of the men promptly exits the log-house and returns shortly thereafter carrying a lit brand, illuminating the scene and revealing Jim's captors.

events.title: Jim's Shocking Discovery and Capture in the Blockhouse
detailed_summary: Jim Hawkins enters the blockhouse to find it occupied by pirates, realizing his worst fears.
He observes the familiar stores but sees no prisoners, leading him to believe his friends have perished, a thought that causes him great distress.
Six buccaneers are present; five are on their feet, appearing disoriented from being awakened from a drunken sleep, while the sixth is pale and wounded, likely the man shot during the earlier attack.
Long John Silver's parrot is on his shoulder, and Silver himself appears more somber and stern than usual, his fine clothes now damaged and dirty.
Silver greets Jim with a semblance of friendliness, acknowledging Jim's unexpected arrival.
He sits and prepares his pipe, instructing one pirate, Dick, for a light and telling the others they don't need to stand for Jim.
Silver expresses his surprise at Jim's appearance, admitting Jim's cleverness has surpassed his expectations.
Jim remains silent, positioned against the wall, facing Silver with outward courage but internal despair.

events.text_segment:
The red glare of the torch, lighting up the interior of the block house, showed me the worst of my apprehensions realized. The pirates were in possession of the house and stores: there was the cask of cognac, there were the pork and bread, as before, and what tenfold increased my horror, not a sign of any prisoner. I could only judge that all had perished, and my heart smote me sorely that I had not been there to perish with them.
There were six of the buccaneers, all told; not another man was left alive. Five of them were on their feet, flushed and swollen, suddenly called out of the first sleep of drunkenness. The sixth had only risen upon his elbow; he was deadly pale, and the blood-stained bandage round his head told that he had recently been wounded, and still more recently dressed. I remembered the man who had been shot and had run back among the woods in the great attack, and doubted not that this was he.
The parrot sat, preening her plumage, on Long John’s shoulder. He himself, I thought, looked somewhat paler and more stern than I was used to. He still wore the fine broadcloth suit in which he had fulfilled his mission, but it was bitterly the worse for wear, daubed with clay and torn with the sharp briers of the wood.
“So,” said he, “here’s Jim Hawkins, shiver my timbers! Dropped in, like, eh? Well, come, I take that friendly.”
And thereupon he sat down across the brandy cask and began to fill a pipe.
“Give me a loan of the link, Dick,” said he; and then, when he had a good light, “That’ll do, lad,” he added; “stick the glim in the wood heap; and you, gentlemen, bring yourselves to! You needn’t stand up for Mr. Hawkins; he’ll excuse you, you may lay to that. And so, Jim”—stopping the tobacco—“here you were, and quite a pleasant surprise for poor old John. I see you were smart when first I set my eyes on you, but this here gets away from me clean, it do.”
To all this, as may be well supposed, I made no answer. They had set me with my back against the wall, and I stood there, looking Silver in the face, pluckily enough, I hope, to all outward appearance, but with black despair in my heart.

events.title: Silver's Persuasion and Revelation of the Doctor's Bargain
detailed_summary: Silver, after a few puffs of his pipe, begins to address Jim, stating his intention to give Jim a piece of his mind.
He claims he has always liked Jim for his spirit, seeing him as a younger version of himself, and had always wanted Jim to join his crew.
Silver asserts that Captain Smollett, though a fine seaman, is too strict, and implies Jim should distance himself from him.
He tells Jim that Doctor Livesey considers him an 'ungrateful scamp' and that Jim's former companions will not accept him back.
Silver concludes that Jim's only viable option, short of forming his own lonely crew, is to join him.
Jim feels a sense of relief upon learning his friends are alive, more so than distress, despite partially believing Silver's claim about their anger towards him for his desertion.
Silver continues, emphasizing Jim's current predicament of being in their hands, but professes a preference for argument over threats.
He presents Jim with a supposed choice: join them if he likes the service, or freely refuse, claiming no fairer offer could be made.
Jim, with a trembling voice, asks if he is truly to answer, feeling the immense pressure and threat of death despite Silver's sneering words.
Silver reassures Jim that no one is rushing him, mockingly stating that they enjoy his company.
Growing bolder, Jim demands to know the current situation, why the pirates are in the blockhouse, and the whereabouts of his friends.
One pirate growls in response, suggesting that knowing 'wot's wot' would make one lucky, but Silver sharply silences him.
Silver then explains to Jim that Doctor Livesey had arrived with a flag of truce the previous morning, informing them the ship was gone.
He admits they might have been drinking and were unaware of the ship's departure until they looked.
Silver recounts bargaining with the doctor, resulting in the pirates gaining the blockhouse, stores, and firewood, while Jim's friends 'tramped' off to an unknown location.

He further specifies that Jim was not part of this treaty, quoting the doctor as saying there were four to leave (one wounded) and that he didn't know or much care about Jim's whereabouts, calling him a 'confound him' and stating they were 'about sick of him'.
